HSY7f4TQcn-yk2vMHZfBqQ.text: I visited Polpo last month on the recommendation of Jay Rayner. I had just been for a beard trim in Liberty's then I whipped down Carnaby Street to this gorgeous little bar.I had a great holiday in Venice last year so as soon as I read about an authentic cicheti bar in Soho I just had to go!  It was packed to the rafters which was very pleasing because it was absolutely freezing outside.It is and it isn't authentic. Unlike cicheti in Venice it is expensive, but, the food is very good. We had a bottle of Prosecco which was excellent and the wine list looked fabulous.A great evening,  and looking forward to my next visit!

9G1L5OlZdYqzSm8iPgE41w.text: Polpo - Pics @ The London FoodieI thought there would be nothing else to add to the media frenzy surrounding "Polpo", the new Italian darling and makers of cicheti or small-eats, or tapas or whatever-you-wanna-call-it in Soho. It's been blogged and highly praised by just about every food blogger in London - but after my disappointing meal there last Saturday, I thought I would put pen to paper and dare to differ.First impressions were excellent - the décor was charming, the front-of-house staff very friendly and the place nearly full and buzzing with a beautiful and trendy crowd at 5:45pm. We started the evening by ordering a couple of their breads, "White Bean Bruschetta" @ £4 and "Wild Mushroom Piadina" @ £4.80, followed by a selection of "cicheti and crostini". The white beans had been cooked in rosemary and were very aromatic and perfectly al dente, a good Italian version of beans on toast. The "Piadina" was similar to a crepe and was filled with fried wild mushrooms. Both breads were nicely prepared although the portions were ludicrously small. We ordered two portions of each, and struggled to share them among the five of us.Our selection of "cicheti and crostini" included "arancini" @ £1.50, "anchovy & chick pea crostini" @ £1.10, "potato and parmesan croquette" @ £1.20 and "salt cod on grilled polenta" @ £2.10. I love Italian "baccala" (salted cod), and cook it frequently at home - I have made a similar dish of flaked salted cod with parsley, garlic and olive oil over grilled polenta a few times at home. These intensely flavoured ingredients should balance beautifully with the blander polenta, and when well made this dish is truly heavenly. Polpo's version however was very disappointing - the polenta was cold and soggy, and the salted cod completely tasteless. We ordered three pieces and we all agreed they were rather poor.The "arancini" were tiny and very uninspiring, and so were the "anchovy & chick pea crostini" and "potato and parmesan croquettes". I tried a bit of each, and struggle to find anything at all to say about them. Completely "passable" comes to mind.The more "substantial" meat and fish dishes that we ordered included "Slow Roasted Duck" @ £6.10, "Calves Liver, Onion and Sage" @ £5.90, "Grilled Flank Steak with Mushroom" @ £6.90, and "Fritto Misto" @ £6.60. We also ordered a portion of "Pork Belly, Radicchio and Hazelnuts" @ £5.70 but it never turned up.Two of these dishes were good - the calves liver was well cooked, although not as delicately flavoured and soft as it should have been, while the "fritto misto" (deep fried whitebait and seafood) was crisp and utterly delicious.The flank steak was beautifully presented but in my opinion lacked seasoning, and the slow roasted duck was unexciting. It was served in a pool of tomato sauce and did not look terribly appetizing. All portions were very ungenerous.To accompany the above we also ordered a portion of "Roast Potatoes and Rosemary" @ £3.70, "Grilled Polenta" @ £3 and "Fennel, Curly Endive and Almonds" @ £3.90. These were all well made and flavoursome, but again the portions were minute.For pudding, we had a few "Affogato al caffe" @ £2.60 each (vanilla ice cream immersed in espresso coffee), "Flourless Orange & Almond Cake" @ £4.40, and "Honey & Walnut Semifreddo" @ £3.80. The affogato tasted just right - both the ice cream and the coffee were of high quality. The orange and almond cake was light and delicious, and I enjoyed it  immensely. I did not try the semifreddo but John seemed impressed with his choice.The wine list was impressive and reasonably priced, with bottles of white and red starting at £15 through to £38. Polpo serves most of its whites and a few reds in 250ml and 500ml measures at no extra cost. A bottle of 750ml will cost £15 while 500ml & 250ml measures will cost £10 and £5 respectively. This is a nice thought, and the flat pricing structure should encourage wine drinkers to try different wine combinations to accompany their cicheti.My dinner companions were old friends from a wine club I used to belong to in Dulwich (Dulwich Wine Society), and therefore our wine choices were good but rather pricey. We had a couple of bottles of Gavi (white) @ £30 each and two of Barbera (red) @ £21 each. The total bill came to £208, including service, or £42 per person. The general consensus was that it was a disappointing and expensive meal and some of us were still peckish at the end of it.Verdict - A clear example of style over substance. Good deep fried fish, good desserts, excellent wine list but tiny, ridiculously tiny portions.  Some of the dishes were seriously disappointing for a restaurant currently the subject of such hype. I am not planning a return visit.

Go2g1VXPcjGOTRvWAJFdtw.text: FoodYUM! But small quantities. Arancini were thimble-sized instead of fist-sized. Don't go there if you're hungry. Really. Don't.And they don't bring you all the food in one shot so you can have the focaccia with, say, the beets. nono. They stagger the delivery and bring one or two dishes at a time, so the impression you get at the end of the meal (and during the meal) is that you haven't eaten much. PriceCame out to about £35-40 per person with a glass of wine or a beer each, and a dessert each. Location, service, etc...Surprised that they don't take reservations, but they don't for dinner. So go early. Like 18:00. By 19:00 it's buzzing and people pass so close to the tables that they could spill your drinks if you leave them too close to the edge. Service is very helpful, but also rather busy, so allow plenty of time for getting your bill, especially if you're heading to a play or the cinema. AmbianceI love the decor of raw stone walls, wooden tables, and delicate lighting. However, the place gets insanely full very quickly, and the music gets so loud that I had to lean into the person next to me in order to hear them properly. It might've been just our table, but this was an eminently clubby volume.

vWQRZaNV7GSnQsW1j5Tuyg.text: Went here for dinner last night with my boyfriend. I was worried that the wait would be ridiculous on a Saturday night, but we were there early-ish (about 7), so the wait was only about 5 mins. We got some delicious Moscow Mules from the bar while we waited, and then we were led to our table at the back.The waitress recommended we go with 3 mains, a veg and some starters/breads. We ended up ordering 4 mains and it turns out our waitress was right. The flank steak, cod cheeks, meatballs and lamb were all delicious and cooked perfectly. The heritage tomatoes were good, but probably not worth £5 for a plate of tomatoes. Our favorite dishes were probably the flank steak, cod cheeks and arancini, which were hot, gooey and cheesy.

iBN3rGlS4fJGzkB7Mj-DWw.text: I had high hopes from the moment this place opened its doors, only working a block away. We strolled in yesterday at about 1pm without a reservation and were offered a seat at the bar.The menu was appetising, and we ordered quickly as we didn't have long. Our drinks arrived straight away and our first order (Polenta topped with Salt Cod) came within 5 minutes. The creamed cod was really tasty but unfortunately the Polenta really let the side down being cold, damp and sweet. I suspect it would have been lovely had the polenta been crispy and hot. Also it was only one rather small piece.Our Tapenade & Tomato Pizette arrived another 5 minutes later, hot crispy and tasty. It was nice but nothing to scream about.We were already halfway through our beers at this point when the food simply stopped coming. We'd probably had 50g of food each and both looked around confused and food kept arriving but nowhere nearby enough to eat. 30+ minutes later we had chased and cajoled and though the staff seemed to be looking into it and promising us of food shortly to arrive nothing did. They were all very sweet and obliging but this didn't seem to help expedite our food.So after almost an hour we'd had a beer each and 75g of food and we cancelled our order to go to the sandwich bar next door. They initially intended to charge for our two tiny pieces of food and beers, though whilst we were in the midst of paying, the manager came over and apologised for the wait and said there would be no need to pay. This was definitely a saving grace on their part, had they not said that the tone of this review would have been much harsher and I would have definitely not returned.All this said; the sweet staff, tasty food (what we received), & nice ambience will make me go back again. I'd really like to experience what all those food reviewers loved so much; surely Giles Coren can't be wrong...3/10 : Definitely some overdue homework

D0bwvTqG8NAW3spzuUP_dw.text: Please refer to my blog for pictures and more: hungryinlondon.com/2010/…  Polpo is the first restaurant which, since I have started this blog, needs to be marked down because of its toilet. I have never seen a toilet that disgusting in a place that is not a boys only student flat share. I will describe all the ghastly details later, but before you completely lose your appetite I shall talk about the food first. Polpo serves tapas-style Italian and this is just such a great idea. Nothing is above 10 pounds and the idea is to order loads of small dishes and share. This is paradise for someone like me who needs to try everything. Not only most food bloggers love this place and I thought the food was decent and the atmosphere was very pleasant. While drinking the cheap and nice enough house red, plates of delicious looking food were carried past us. The staff was lovely and efficient and we got a big bottle of tab water ( I just learn to appreciate this more and more). We started our meal by trying a few of the crostini. We wanted one of each but the waiter pointed out that they were very small and we ended up ordering two of each. In the end they were not that small after all and we wasted already half of our appetite on bread which was a shame really. The best probably was the salmon, dill and horseradish crostini (2 each). The anchovy and chickpea crostini (1 each) was interesting and not unpleasant at all. The least successful were the chicken liver crostini (1.5 each). I love the Italian chicken liver pate usually, but this one was under-seasoned and bland. Even though I would have wanted the bread to be a bit thinner, this is a really nice snack with a glass of wine. Spinach, parmesan and soft egg pizetta (5.5) was enjoyable but did not rock my world. I would not necessarily order it again, although I rather enjoyed the crisp dough and the well seasoned spinach. An absolute winner was the beetroot with rocket and walnut pesto (5). The sweetness of the beetroot, the bitterness of the rocket and the small pieces of walnuts were such a delicious combination that we regretted at this point that we were sharing We all enjoyed the Mackerel Tartare with Horseradish (6). The mackerel tasted almost like ceviche, marinated in lemon juice until cooked through the acid. The horseradish was a bit too creamy for my taste, but nevertheless a lovely dish. Strozzapreti with duck ragu were very nice too. The pasta which was obviously home-made was cooked exactly the way I like it, perfectly al dente and the ragu was well balanced. I would actually quite liked to have some parmesan with it, but we did not get any offered and when the waiter came past next we had already finished. One criticism however  the dish was lukewarm when it was served. How good would it have been actually hot! I love the fact that Polpo serves some small desserts. We tried the ricotta and chocolate crumble (2.50)  two pieces of cake just enough to satisfy our urge for something sweet after dinner. Unfortunately however the cake was disappointing. Too dry and you could neither taste the chocolate nor the ricotta very much. More successful was the Sgroppino (4.5) . Nice place, nice (although not amazing) food and then the toilet. I should have made a picture, but I was so shocked, so please forgive me the lack of photographic evidence. No toilet paper in any of the two cubicles. On the toilet seat were several spots of dried-up urine and on the floor were stains that might have been crusted remnants of vomitus. The wash basin looked like it had not been cleaned for weeks. Stains and dust and dirty glasses everywhere. This is the state of a toilet you would expect in a student nightclub at 6 in the morning, not at a fancy restaurant at 6 in the evening. I usually don't bother too much about toilets, but this was too much and reduced my otherwise pleasant experience at Polpo.

WwE_QUKpG6ZLUmWRbocL8A.text: Great quick Italian with excellent veggie options.  Fennel salad and broad bean bruschetta are outstanding with a good red.  The beak street one is pretty small but nice atmosphere, service is really friendly and prompt.  I like that they are still consistent having opened a few now and that it's a go to option when you haven't booked a table, ok there's a wait but with a bottle of wine you soon forget about that!

wZ9JMxDFMlaSNdRmrKu5OQ.text: I really liked Polpo.  Had lunch here and ordered way to much but at least we had a chance to try everything.  It's tapas styled but the portions are big.  The quality of the food was really good and the polpettos and lamb dish we had were top notch.  I thought the dishes were fairly creative and it had a very cosy feel.  My only issue with the place is that it's line up only - no reservations.

9Y0CP_ThQsiNu46_UvrMlA.text: It's not often that I find myself going to a restaurant in London twice in quick succession but the quality of the food, the ambience and the lovely staff had me dragging B back for a cheeky Sunday lunch after a lovely mid-week dinner. I had been meaning to give Polpo a try for some time but being an impatient kind of guy on the couple of occasions I rocked up around 8pm I could never be bothered to wait the estimated hour or so for a table (no bookings in the evening) so usually ended up in the nearby branch of Brindisa. However, I finally decided to get my act together and turned up on a Wednesday evening at 5.45 and we pretty much had a choice of all the tables or bar seats. However, be warned there was not a table to be had by 6.30!! We grabbed a table in the restaurant, got ourselves an Aperol and a Campari Spritz, and set about studying the beautifully constructed menu which doubles as your place mat. For a grazing fella such as myself these Italian (well, Venetian) small plate menus are just a joy and allow the palate to get a good run out. The staff on both occasions I have eaten here have been brilliant - laid back, friendly yet very professional. They will generally recommend around 5 plates between two but my personal preference is to break it up and have three plates, see where that takes your taste buds and then order another two or perhaps three plates if you are really hungry. The staff will find this no problem and may even complement you on your desire to get the best out of what Polpo has to offer. This approach also has the advantage of giving you a bit of space to work with on the somewhat small tables. So to the food: start with a couple of nibbles to go with your aperitifo. The parmesan and potato croquettes are delicious as are the smoked salmon and horseradish crostino. I would advise caution with bread selection which is fantastic but you don't want to blow up before you have even really begun. Having said that the spinach and egg pizzetta and the crostini are both to die for!! In fact every dish I have eaten here has been pretty damn fine but stand outs are the prawns with chick peas, spaghetti with clams, the meat-balls, broccoli with anchovies and of course the roasted squash with prosciutto. I have to confess I have not had the appetite to make it to the dolce but the selection looks good and from what I saw on the surrounding tables was going down very well. Wine selection was short, well edited and for London fairly reasonably priced. The house white was fine and was available by the 1/4 litre for a fiver. Coffee was as good as you would expect and tap water was served chilled by the bottle. The crowd seem to be a mixture of foodie locals with a good dose of in the know tourists. Very popular with the late 20's and thirtysomething types and all great for people watching. Very few children running free just makes it all so much better!! On our return for some Sunday snackage we arrived at 1pm without booking and managed to secure a couple of seats at the bar on the right as you enter - top notch position for people watching with plenty of space and fairly cozy if you are in a romantic mood. I was particularly impressed with our barmaid who was very friendly, helpful and had impeccable music taste - it's been a long time since I have heard the Slits sounding so good with a Sunday lunch. We left to meet our old friends the Duncan clan from the Granite City in the Old Coffee Shop Pub a couple of doors down the road well fed and in great spirits - many thanks Polpo. All things considered this would be one of my top recommendations if you happen to be in central London and want to eat some great food at very reasonable prices. Book your lunch spot now!!

Wxy_osHvmlPIdSBBbgmYig.text: Tapas. Mmm, what springs to mind? Overpriced tip-bits of meat, cheese and olives in little bowls in somewhere called La Taskmaster. But wait, this is ITALIAN tapas. Just like the people who in the 1980s thought pasta was boring and now have their own pasta machine and mile high pepper grinder, I have been converted to Tapas. If someone is going to serve little tip-bits of food in a selection so everyone can share they need to be a) super tasty b) adventurous. Every time I go to Polpo they get this just right: I've never really heard of any of the dishes and they are deeelicious. It gets fairly busy in here but ring a few hours before to book a table, and you should be fine. They do manage to cram people in but the atmosphere is great, the staff are friendly and efficient, and it's not so pricey. And it's Soho! If you're a Tapas cynic like me, free your mind and try Polpo. And make sure you pick out some random dishes from the menu - as some others have mentioned the cuttlefish in it's own ink is brilliant!

SO4_mfpzbLQFb3StXxZ1Ig.text: Wonderful atmosphere and very good service but the preparation of Polpo's actual dishes is rather hit or miss. The arancini, made with rice, peas and mozzarella are nice while their croquette cousins are a bit bland, but the batter for both is excellent. The mackerel on polenta - tasteless and greasy. The fritto misto - avoid; it's surprisingly devoid of flavour, limp and seems to have been fried well before being served. The cuttlefish with ink gremolata is unusual and tasty as is the pizzetta bianca. The pork belly with hazel nuts and radicchio is attractively presented and adequately flavourful. So ... choose your cichetto wisely and a satisfactory dining experience may be had but stay away from that fritto misto!

HEEbgV-Y-7W2pXRHCdp7xw.text: I get great pleasure from recommending places for people to connect with the mythical place called "Fooddom". If this review was based purely on the food , there would be 4 stars plus. But, alas this is not the case . My first course consisted of a hostess who gave us a 1 1/2 hour quote time for a table and when we returned  at 59 minutes to check in, our name had been called , we were no longer on the list , and we apparently told that we needed to be here the whole time . Which of course , was not the case .. Too bad your out  luck was our 2nd course .and it was our choice to just sit in "time out " until a table became  available . A bar stool opened up, we sat and enjoyed the rest of the meal  with a lovely and professional bar team . The hostess was our first impression and set the tone .  As we sat, a fight started to break out between 2 men . One can only assume that they must've just finished chatting with the hostess.

zSazpm0PUm63kDqrLSrZSg.text: I'm surprised that this restaurant has received anything higher than one star.  My husband and I decided to try Polpo as it was mentioned in the guide: "eat.shop.London". We have used this guide for other cities such as New York and Chicago, and have had very good luck with the restaurant suggestions, but sadly, this recommendation was way off base.We ordered:Arancini - bland and boringMortadella Wrap - worthlessCod Cheeks with Lentils - okBeef and Pork Meatballs - ok (as in boring)Potato Parmesan Croquette - Tesco has better offeringsPork Belly with Radicchio and Hazelnuts - unpalatableThis restaurant that presents itself as "local" and inspired by traditional Venetian eateries had nothing but bland, pre-made (read frozen and re-heated) food. We should have known that there was a problem when part of our order was served within five minutes.  It's hard to believe that something that is supposed to be cooked to order would be prepared so quickly. There was nothing unique in any way on the menu. The only dish that seemed to be authentic was the Cod, but even that was unremarkable.  In fact, the pork belly was unfit to eat.  All fat, no crispy skin or meat and a flavor that was borderline rancid.  Another couple next to us had ordered the same and we checked to see if theirs had been any better.  When their plates were removed, they had eaten about the same as us:  practically nothing, after searching in vain for something redeeming.Contrary to other reviews, we thought the service was just fine. The hostess was very pleasant and helpful when we asked about making reservations the day before. We sat at the bar and the bartender was very informative and attentive.If you are a tourist looking for a great local restaurant in Polpo, you will surely be disappointed.  Keep looking because there are many more places worth your appetite and business.

AuwcPdVL60mITLrWDxzCTQ.text: One of my favourite places. The tapas-style, Italian home cooking in a casual environment can be the perfect antidote to a rainy day. The only criticism I have is that it is always packed and the wait can be long, but then bookings are taken so I'm being unreasonable. I just want to be able to turn up and pig out, and I can't do that because Polpo is so popular. But the more form-fitting items in my wardrobe are grateful. Also the dessert portions are quite small. But again, my wardrobe thanks the gods who deigned to spare it further undue stretching. The decor is perfect: Part French cafe, part industrial chic and clearly Italian. The naked lightbulbs create a warming effect to soften the translucent skylight in the ceiling. Tables are staffed with plain glassware and paper menus. Staff are friendly and knowledgeable. Speaking of which, my favourites off the current menu are the strozzapretti in dug ragu (beautifully cooked duck in a green peppercorn sauce) and the fig/walnut/goat cheese/honey brucschetta. Simple, yet each ingredient is perfectly toasted/roasted/seasoned/combined. The wine list is limited but reasonably priced. If you like to eat like I do, then beware that a plate here and a plate there can add up (if you, like me, lack self restraint in the face of deliciousness).

LO3OsprqMyoVHicv3CYoJg.text: Arrived last night close to 8pm and was told the wait would be 1 hour 45 mins. After some debate, we decided to wait it out at the bar with a bottle of wine. We were seated in about a hour, which was a nice little surprise! :)Ambiance is nice but food is just okay. We had bruschetta, mozzarella, prosciutto, veal, risotto, and the tomato salad. Service was quite quirky because it was our server's first night. She didn't know all the answers to our questions but very willingly found the answers for us, which was much appreciated. All in all, a good time. Will I go back? Not sure yet...

Wb1ZWoB8fti3ZiLjsfkPGQ.text: Cracking place. I like to sit at the bar. The food comes quickly in nice portions and apparently the menu changes with the seasons. Simple things done deliciously. Check the photos on the web site. The waitress in the Bowie t shirt is even better in the flesh. This is an outstanding place for quick eats and a natter over a red wine or two.

iAbIp2hUkRYRUl-cl_hEfw.text: Italian Tapas? I was confused. Why, I asked myself, would I want to eat little bits of pizza when I could just eat a 12" bad boy from Domino's? I blame my English state education; Italian - that's spaghetti innit? Well, as Polpo more than adequately taught me, it aint all pizza (blud). From cuttlefish cooked in its own ink (I hadn't previously realised this was possible!) to slow roast duck, Polpo gave me a schooling in what proper Italian food is all about. The restaurant itself, kind of a nouveau rustic feel, was cosy and atmospheric, without feeling overdone or cramped, and the service attentive and prompt. Polpo also seems to have achieved the impressive feat of being equally at home catering for business lunches, groups of friends, or romantic couples. Lastly I have to second Andrew's recommendation. If you have time for a pint after dinner, check out the Old Coffee House (qype.co.uk/place/77147-T…)

wXD3hhd-4sKd2IT4WLKa-w.text: We reserved a table for 7 yesterday at lunch time. When we arrived, the table - despite the place being packed up to the limit - was still available and seated 7 just fine (round table, so much more convenient for larger groups). We ordered each one a starter and everything on the main menu to give us the full experience - and we weren't disappointed! The dishes and drinks were served quite fast (given the full restaurant) and I wouldn't be able to choose which one was my favourite....all of them did taste great and had something special to it! Included in our "everything-from-the-menue" experience was squid in its own ink, mussels & clams, octopus salad, pork belly, fennel salad, meatballs (polpette), cured meats and so many more dishes, mostly around 5-6 pounds for a main, starters around 1-2 pounds. Definitely a place to go if you want to have good food in a bustling place....don't try to do a quiet and calm night out there!

7ERMg3bdDnK9C-XLXUOSig.text: Wow! damn is the food special, unique and TASTY here!! i tried rabbit for the first time here and it was DELICIOUS!! and the lamb!! oh the lamb!! and the asparagus!! small portions, that's the only problem...but good place to pick a few things and share!

ChQ0kiIZnKP7DT-1QO_rbA.text: My verdict is the atmosphere makes the dining experience better. The tapas bathed in soft light from the Edison bulbs and the tin ceiling tiles make the decor very cosy, romantic, hipster. Reminds me of the aesthetic in NYC's LES.  The food is ok, passable but not the best tapas, ever. The Bresaola rocket was great, had a nice sharp dressing to bring out the flavor. The steak and mushrooms were pretty tasty. However its namesake octopus salad was pretty mediocre.  Overall great for an incredible ambiance and the food is not bad.

jKPP04x2boge-I_SdRIpqw.text: Overhyped/overrated/overpriced. The concept of this restaurant seems to be a means to charge main course prices for a starter sized plate of food. Mostly the dishes are tasty, but £5 for a plate of steamed kale is an insult.

hHJejQNVzRmH0S8V71KfHw.text: I came to Polpo after enjoying some time soaking in the sun at the park. Again, I found myself heading here on one of those random weekends when it was a last minute plan to have dinner and it would be wishful thinking to go anywhere that is on your eat list without a booking. So where do you go? Somewhere that doest even take reservations at all of course.    Polpo is very very dark especially at dinner time. You could barely see your food let alone take decent pictures.   Smoked salmon, horseradish and dill crostino £4Silky salmon on crusty crostino with the horseradish giving an added kick. What is not to like?  Wild mushroom piadina £6 Fritto misto £7Nice little bits of fried morsels. Same as in Da Polpo, they do this well. Fennel and curly endive salad, almonds £4We figured we should also order something healthy and this was chosen. Nice but nothing spectacular.  Duck ragu, strozzapreti and green peppercorns £7This was good. Gamey, earthy and rich, we had to fight each other to eat this. Chocolate salami £2Ricotta and chocolate crumble £2Sfogliatina, zabaglione cream and pomegranate £5Tiramisu pot £4Desserts were decent but unmemorable

zyEiu8kkdX5ZN0NFruj28A.text: I quite like Polpo. The drinks are normally excellent concoctions; even if I don't like the sound of them I certainly like the taste of them. The food can be a bit hit and miss, but after a couple of visits you'll find the gems. The best thing we had last visit was goat's cheese bruschetta with a basil oil. It was so good that I made my own basil oil at home the next day!

gtxi3tbXQfE40H9PlSZrjQ.text: We all know how much it sucks when our younger sibling outshines us.  And boy, in the world of sibling rivalry, Polpo is the stodgy older sis to the much hotter, more outgoing little sister, Polpetto.  We made it in just under the wire on Saturday night before things got super busy.  We sat down to a lovely bottle of red and a sickening display of PDA at the table next to us--wouldn't think it the most relevant info to the review, but it is in terms of people watching, which was fantastic!Like all siblings, these sisters share some qualities.  Both are bacaro-style places serving the same types of Venetian-inspired small plates.  I got that vibe at Polpo for sure, but everything just felt a little rundown and dirty.  It seems like the place would really benefit from a fresh coat of paint.We ordered the arancini and bocconcini, which were okay, but nothing superb.  Both could have used a hit of acid--balsamic or lemon or something.  We had the spinach, parm, and egg pizzetta, that paled in comparison to the pork shoulder and pepper pizzetta at Polpetto.  The other dish that stuck out to me was the cuttlefish risotta, that we had also had at Polpetto.  It was beautifully done at Polpetto--and the reason we ordered it again; here it was undercooked and rather a turn-off.   I'm pretty sure I'll be sticking with the cooler little sister from now on.

bOcwqmYanXK-8JieU3STLQ.text: Polpo is most decidedly not a pizza place (desite the annoying Qype designation which forces it into the same category as the awful Pizza Express), and is extremely reasonably priced for such high quality food. They specialise in small dishes of the type found in the Venetian countryside (if that isn't impossible) - but more substantial than tapas. In fact we left the choice of food entirely to the owner/manager Russell Norman who russelled up 16 different dishes between the four of us and they were delicious, though as we also had two bottles of wine (a great Gavi di Gavi and an excellent Lacrima Morro d'Alba) and with only three of us drinking them (the other was on whisky....) our concentration became somewhat impaired. Despite only having opened two weeks ago, service was terrific - friendly without people rushing up saying 'is it ok?' every few minutes, and the atmosphere in the old Soho house (once lived in by Canaletto) was warm and cosy, and packed to the rafters with smart young things. Food came to £95 for four (the less said about our bar bill the better) and was great value for such a fun evening. Russell Norman has harnessed the power of the blogosphere to promote his restaurant and twitters amusingly about it. He is thus one of the first to tweet about his customers instead of the other way round. No doubt it will be a point of honour to get a mention in his nightly postings.

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Polpo is a bit dark for a good photo. This is the service bar next to the kitchens.

_S91VZfdFHmIoTIoiAB7DQ.text: Walking out of the elite event, we spotted this little place and went in to grab food after being soaked in gin for the previous 3 1/2 hours.The food was excellent...I loved the asparagus, the potatoes and the lamb. Everything that I put in my mouth was super good (as far as I can remember....oh lovely gin :) and the service was super duper speedy. I'm not  huge tapas fan but this one was quite excellent!The only complaint really is that we asked for a carafe of wine for the 4 of us and said carafe was the size of a large wine glass. Clearly, they had no idea who they were serving or they would have brought us each one ;)

ctJawQfFHpxlRfmd3vQSgQ.text: Though we had to wait for an hour for our table, two friends and I found plenty of time to catch up over some complimentary dishes at the bar. A real trendy gig.

xxBQvLZRzSkorT2cpO8GDQ.text: The veal meatball smash is always a smashing success. I took my cousin for the first time and she was dying to like the plate but thankfully stopped short. The coleslaw with black sesame was a dream and better than anything I've tasted in the US (who love their slaw).

KiEySI1qvgB8wo8Mw-oSfg.text: wow the meatballs/polpettes are the best i've ever tasted. The calamari is fantastic. Its a very popular place and so be prepared to wait as its a small venue. Unfortunately as its so cramped its like i am sharing my meal with fellow diners and its awkward to leave your table when finished. If you are looking for good food and dont mind the wait or cramped conditions then this is the place for you, as for me i want to go back and order the polpettes

c2osVGTzBKN8qtItfs8MPA.text: Bargain little Italian in Soho, wine in a small glass, meatballs to die for along with a selection of little dishes tapas style. The goat cheese and grape bread is gorgeous. Atmosphere is that of a busy trattoria but randomly playing Oasis in the background. Wanna go back and try more dishes.

6JW7zUiZxE7FnXuFbSCbAQ.text: When you're doing Italian tapas style in the vicinity of Bocca di Lupo you have got to be brilliant to match up. Polpo is certainly very good but just doesn't quite match the same standards. Admittedly the dishes are cheaper but also not quite as plentiful.The real acid test for me was the seafood linguine. Both restaurants use the same brand of dried linguine but whereas Bocca was sublime with perfectly al dente pasta, Polpo's pasta was slightly overcooked and just nowhere near as tasty.You also have to worry about a restaurant when there is a dish on the menu that the waitress very strongly recommends you to avoid. Here it is the chocolate and orange salami.  We were advised under no circumstances to order it. Whether it is actually good or not becomes irrelevant. If a restaurant has a dish on the menu that the staff dislike that much then there has to be some problem going on.The saving grace of this place is the friendliness of the staff. They made good recommendations on the dishes, although to the frustration of the chef they were occasionally slow getting dishes out.I suspect that if I went on a less busy night with a slightly less noisy atmosphere I might enjoy this place more, but when you consider that for just a little more money Bocca di Lupo is a 5 minute walk away it'll be hard bringing myself back.

5oFkXlcCptSBTZLcobaE9Q.text: What we ordered:Pizzetta bianca: flat bread with some soft white cheeses and a white sauce, delicate and not overwhelming.Wild mushroom piadina: delicious!  tons of sauteed mushrooms, hints of white wine and garlic, all folded into a light crust.Beet root salad with walnut pesto: Yum!Zucchini: thinly sliced, tossed with olive oil and light basil and parm.Polenta: grilled, which added a hint of a char taste... super great.Green Beans, cobnuts, and fresh mozzarella: and by fresh mozzarella, I mean FRESH!  The nuts added a little earthy and salty vibe and the beans were cooked perfectly!Pecorino: sliced thin, served with pear and crostini. and Dessert:  a Flourless Orange and Almond cake with a scoop of mascarpone All in all this was an amazing restaurant.  There was a wait at the beginning due to the no reservation rule, but it was fine to wait while we enjoyed a delicious hand crafted Manhattan and Old Fashioned from the bar.  The food was delicious, especially when considering price, and the service was timely and well informed of their menus and wine list.enjoy.

zUAytbenjv2cxD83PTw12A.text: Polpo provides great Italian dishes in tapas style -- it is that straightforward.  There is nothing complicated in stating you provide Venetian style tapas.   It has the appearance of being very crowded when you first arrive but that has more to do with the location of the bar.  We were seated within 10 minutes and quickly enjoyed an number of delicious dishes including pumpkin and prosciutto, flank steak with truffles and a rather understated dish of runner beans.  The place has a great vibe, it is a simple concept and I will definitely return.

s-03XRo4zhJeR92MkvivOQ.text: Just a busy area.  Where is a new yorker to eat?  Luck would have it there was a seat for 2 at the bar counter.  After a long day of shopping, the crowd didnt bother me a bit.   The service could have been more attentive but when we did get it, it was very good.  To be honest i dont remember what we ate but whatever it was i recommend them all, so just go.

2AYVWRpCl4uFKgCwCWeUJQ.text: It seams reading a funny review of an Aberdeen Angus steak house can bring you more than a smile, it can also lead you to a quality eating establishment :-) The author mentioned his desire to lead the angus customers by the hand and into one of the other amazingly priced restaurants in London e.g. Polpo.After checking it out I also learnt that Jay Rayner was a fan, and my tastes seem to be aligned with his.  I couldn't get in the first Friday I tried, although we did walk in casually at 9pm as a group of 3, doh!  It wasn't all bad as we ate about 100 chicken wings in Busaba Eathai, no joke.I went back on a Monday night at about 9pm and it was still mega busy, every table was full but we managed to get seated in less than 15 minutes.  We ordered grilled polenta, liver and onion, pork belly, pumpkin etc. about 8 dishes in total and they were all fantastic, particularly the liver!  They also sell a lovely machiato for £1.60, so cheap. The bill for two, including service, coffee and a £27 bottle of Valpolicella, was £69!!! I thought that was an absolute bargain, we basically could have scrapped the coffees and gone for house wine and it would have been £25-30 a head, BARGAIN!Not sure if there are any tips apart from find the dude with the clipboard when you get in, he's the man that'll get you a table, all the others are just milling around serving drinks and stuff!Will I be returning? For SURE! But make sure you have a backup as they'll probably laugh you out of the door.PS I liked the lights in the place, all exposed and Shoreditchy.

QTGWxvPM7hzwx3HjmLCFuw.text: I came to Polpo after enjoying some time soaking in the sun at the park. Again, I found myself heading here on one of those random weekends when it was a last minute plan to have dinner and it would be wishful thinking to go anywhere that is on your eat list without a booking. So where do you go? Somewhere that doest even take reservations at all of course.Polpo is very very dark especially at dinner time. You could barely see your food let alone take decent pictures.Smoked salmon, horseradish and dill crostino £4Silky salmon on crusty crostino with the horseradish giving an added kick. What is not to like?Wild mushroom piadina £6Fritto misto £7Nice little bits of fried morsels. Same as in Da Polpo, they do this well.Fennel and curly endive salad, almonds £4We figured we should also order something healthy and this was chosen. Nice but nothing spectacular.Duck ragu, strozzapreti and green peppercorns £7This was good. Gamey, earthy and rich, we had to fight each other to eat this.Chocolate salami £2Ricotta and chocolate crumble £2Sfogliatina, zabaglione cream and pomegranate £5Tiramisu pot £4Desserts were decent but unmemorable

HolTx5rpro2M_hjQZDyt2Q.text: Venetian tapas?? What?? I've never heard of 'em, but I gave them a chance.  This seems like one of those places foodies recommend. We went on a Wednesday night and even then it was still busy. We got there about 8ish and it was an hour and a bit wait.  No worries though as they had a good selection of wines :)We finally were seated and we ordered LOTS (waiting makes me hungrier). I don't remember everything, but remembered the fried polenta was AMAZING, as was the risotto.I'm no food critic or even a foodie, but I just wasn't bowled over by anything, nor would I think to immediately recommend this place to anyone.

qOHeuHtaPTpbwB1-fqENjA.text: A MUST GO restaurant! Delicious food (personal faves are the chopped liver crostini- I'm not a HUGE fan of liver but here it is just spot on! And the risotto nero with cuttlefish and squid rings- fresh, simple, delicious cooking). Very well priced, relaxed staff and atmosphere. You can pop in for a couple of small sharing plates and a caraf of wine for approx £15 per head. No bookings taken for dinner so arrive before 7pm to avoid the queue!

4LsIcfD4LpfV_S65YpNsaw.text: A firm favourite of mine, and the rest of London so it seems. It's success has a lot to do with the restaurant's savvy use of Twitter as a self-promotion tool (check them out at @PolpoSoho), but even more to do with fabulous food and a gorgeous atmosphere to boot.I was first taken here by the lovely Mel Seasons (fakeplasticnoodles.com) for lunch, and one of our group was vegetarian. We perused the tapas-style menu of Italian cicheti (which just means small portions) and small plates. Our waiter was great, explaining the dishes and ordering format (plates come out as they're ready unless you state otherwise). Both meat-eaters and plant lovers alike had a great meal. I fell back in love with polenta (grilled), which I'd previously marked down for being bland. The mini pizza was divine, and the spinach with chili was delicious.Since then, I've been back and back. Friends love it, colleagues love it. Every single person I've taken there has had fun. It's got a great atmosphere (the 18th century building it's housed in used to belong to Caneletto, famous for his paintings of Venice), and it just calls out for afternoons of red wine, espresso and chatter.Don't be put off by the crowd at the front door, it can be misleading as people sometimes crush in to drink at the bar. I haven't ever actually had to wait for a table there. Though, it only sits 55, so pick your times carefully.Prices are pretty good for the quality of food you get. Though the cicheti and crostini itself are priced per portion (£1.20 upwards), so make sure you order per person. The rest are smaller dishes, so can be shared. Wine is average cost for London, and the cocktails - which come in Italian style glass cups - start from £5.Polpo also has a good sized private room for lunches or dinners, that can seat 30. I haven't been in there yet, but I'm thinking about booking it for my birthday!

8oowEi6bO2wII5FkgV03tQ.text: Very hyped place so finally got the chance to visit it. Must say that it was a slight dissapointement.I love italian food but somehow the menu felt forced and could not really find anything I fancied.In the end the meatballs, risotto side and chocolate salami dessert were very good.The thing you should not come for here is pasta, but on the other hand the ambiance is very good and it's not too expensive. Perfectly suited for sharing a bottle of wine and some nibbles.I'd recommend it for sure - but it's not as fantastic as I've read here and there.

vLz101vyr-AlygqdNw9ACA.text: wow the meatballs/polpettes are the best i've ever tasted. The calamari is fantastic. Its a very popular place and so be prepared to wait as its a small venue. Unfortunately as its so cramped its like i am sharing my meal with fellow diners and its awkward to leave your table when finished.If you are looking for good food and dont mind the wait or cramped conditions then this is the place for you, as for me i want to go back and order the polpettes

7-wQMVn5NwLFrJF5alTQKQ.text: BAM. Tonight's meal sealed the 5-star deal for me. This time I went with two foodies who, dare I say, enjoy the art of eating even more than I - which is a sight to be seen. Especially when we were presented with the menu. Eyes as big as saucers, we soon were tucking into apricot and sage rabbit terrine, prosciutto with buffalo mozzarella, and the most amazing pizzetta bianca I've ever indulged in. We then ordered six more dishes... and bread... and dessert... and ohmyGOD it was so good. All of it. So good.  The 45 minute wait went by in a flash due to the sassy bartenders, stiff cocktails and seats at the bar. Match that with the atmosphere that I mentioned in my previous review, and this place is just an overall win.Go with your fellow foodies and sample your heart out!

USyvjxJof6TtaC5iEnHtcQ.text: I'm also surprised this place hasn't received higher ratings, like its sister restaurants in other parts of London have. I went here last night for a friend, and had a really nice experience. We waited about half an hour for a table, but got drinks at the bar first. They had a really, really excellent dark and stormy (£7). The rum was Havana Club, a sort of forbidden fruit for us Americans with our dumb Cuban embargo. I have had a lot of dark and stormies, and this was honestly the best I'd ever had. Not too much ice, so it wasn't watered down after five minutes. When we were seated, we ordered a bottle of wine and a number of the small plates. My nominal knowledge is only of California wine (of which there is absolutely none in London, it seems), so I moved on to the next best thing for me, and picked a barbera (£25). Their wine list is small, but apparently carefully chosen as the wine was really nice, smooth, and fruity. A good red to accompany relatively light dishes. We ordered the:- Arancini (just OK -- I'm not a fan of the concept generally)- Chopped chicken liver crostino (absolutely yummy -- almost like a pate or something)- Goat cheese, roasted grape, pine nut, honey crostini (a MUST have!)- Lamb and pistachio meatballs (solid, but not memorable)- Calamari and radish salid (solid, but not memorable)- Chili and garlic prawns (another must have -- super flavorful, a good amount of chili and spice!)- Tirimisu pot (to split -- very nice). The reasons it receives four stars instead of five are 1) somewhat inattentive and mediocre service (the downside of a no tipping culture), and 2) a few dishes that were "just OK" as opposed to really standing out. Wow, looking at that list, what an alcoholic/fat kid night we had. But everything was very tasty, and I'd definitely go back. The bill was ~£45/person inclusive, so not cheap at all, but not a bad value given the quality of the meal. I've had some terrible food in London, and this was a very nice change fromm that.

ab1pWUWwFrvoBm5VLL-Gdg.text: After hanging out like sardines packed into the negroni bar downstairs (an experience not to be missed!) we were finally seated and our server helped guide our order of 4 items in the right direction which allowed us to have a lovely meal with a bottle of wine.The Pizzette withe green olive, white anchovy, and basil was a delicious standout, as was the Mackeral tartare with horseradish and carta di musica. The Spicy pork and fennel meatballs were really flavorful, and the only miss of the evening lacking something was the Pear, gorgonzola, and chicory salad.Will definitely return!

3A06y_yRDXgcQ6KgqN2AOQ.text: Had lunch here. Very busy and didn't have a reservation so was offered some seating at the bar. This worked out fine and it was actually pretty comfy seating for a bar area. Had the classic meatballs and a pizzette (the prosciutto, mozzarella & rocket one, yum!), and really enjoyed it. My lunch date had the lamb and was pleased. I really liked the atmosphere, cute little Italian place in Soho to definitely check out!

hFGOwDUEoFVVSiG7jPywDw.text: Surprised this place isn't more highly rated. Only reason I mark them down is the service isn't a good as I would have liked, but the food mostly made up for it.Arrived with no reservation - 45 minute wait in the bar downstairs. Got a bit worried when those who arrived after us started getting seated so asked what happened and were seating pretty promptly at the bar. Bar is fine for eating and if anything probably a bit faster so not something to snub your nose at.We ordered 7 things - this was WAY too much. Didn't even get close to finishing.RECOMMEND in order of preference:Goat cheese, roasted grape & honey bruschettaCured pork shoulder & pickled pepperAranciniVeal & porcini meatballsCauliflower & Fontina gratinDO NOT recommend:Cod cheeks and lentils - I really didn't like this. Unless you love lentils a lot I wouldn't get it.Duck Papardele - this was actually OK but really needed salt. House wine is good too. Would definitely go back as there are more things I would love to try.

EGrLcVHTd--tJqgSy8c-KQ.text: Arrived without a reservation and had a few drinks downstairs -- not a very comfortable space, but better than waiting in the entrance as I'd done before.  A decent negroni, albeit on the tiny side.Service was fine, albeit a bit hectic. We ordered:Chopped Liver Crostini -- very smooth liver; standout dish of the meal.Arancini -- dry, flavourless, and almost non-existent cheese inside. Not great.Spinach, Parm, and egg Pizette -- great crust, reasonably tasty, but extremely salty.  Should've been called the Dead Sea PizzaChick pea, spinach & ricotta meatball -- a mealy flavourless piece of crapSliced flank steak -- came covered with rocket, steak was slightly overcooked (flank should be bordering on too rare, this was almost served well done).  Edible, but about on par with getting a steak at a weatherspoons (not that I've done that).Some other dish which was a pasta served with the chickpea meatball mixture. Wasn't keen to be served the same dish twice, esp because it was crap in both incarnations.I used to love Polpo, but it was really really disappointing. I will never go back.  I hate to suggest that this group is a victim of its own success, but opening so many places in a short period of time can be very difficult for restauranteurs -- I hope for their sake they can find equilibrium.

yY1PKY1JNpPUXxzyHr2ksg.text: I had a quite mediocre experience here. I read other yelpers' reviews and just cannot comprehend how did they had such a lovely time and our night was ruined by dodgy service and food that was just good at most. I am very frustrated from our dinner and I just had to let it all out.

X1V188xyKZwpvft8pi9cWw.text: Good place to go for sharing and trying lots of small plates. Excellent Campari bar downstairs, great atmosphere, perfect destination for date night.

G44MdBQ8a0U7oS1ZPiYjsQ.text: I visited Polpo with my lady last Saturday night and had a great time. Being a peak time, we expected there to be a wait and there was - like 1.5 hours.  When faced with that you situation can give up and find somewhere else to eat, or you do the sensible thing and head to the basement bar and put away some excellent cocktails. There's a very serious negroni being made down there and it's amazing how a few of them can make the time fly by.When we made it upstairs we had the polpette, cod cheeks, spinach and egg pizzette, some grilled polenta and the brussel tops. All were great although it was probably a bit much for two people but you can put that down to a bit of reckless post-cocktail ordering.Can't wait to go back.

WSMpSORGg7Qa5cVVgdNRLg.text: Small plate dining, associated with the tapas of Spain and the mezze of Greece and Turkey, appear all over the region. The less known Venetian equivalent, chicchetti, have many similarities. Combinations of meat, fish and vegetables, often served with bread or polenta. Can't go wrong. In the past few years, alongside several excellent new Spanish joints, we've also been lucky enough to welcome both Bocca di Lupo and Polpo to Soho. The latter, a buzzy little place on Beak Street, was opened by Russell Norman (ex Caprice Holdings) to solid reviews and even more solid word of mouth. A strict no bookings policy at this 'locals' restaurant led to regular queues down the street once the word had spread. He's just done it again too, with Polpetto, a beautiful little matchbox above the French House.  Decorwise, it's got that Soho House style shabby chic look down to pat. low light from bare bulbs and simple furniture bely the thought that has gone into the joint. The staff are friendly and surprisingly relaxed considering the unruly mash of drinkers and diners crammed into their tiny bar space. A smatter of seats aside the bar are the best in the house, keeping you cozily ensconced in the amiable bar crowd. It's not a place for the shrinking violet. The Literary Lady and I are certainly no violets but we struggled to make ourselves heard at times. Like little brother Polpetto, this is definitely somewhere to come and meet and mingle and if you grab a bite, then it's a result. The atmosphere is key to the experience.  But what of the food? There was a fair amount of it that grabbed us on the throwaway paper menus, and plenty of tasty morsels certain to soak up a lovely big Sagiovese, well priced for house at £16.50. We went for five plates to start and added another two on at the end, greedily tempted by a neighbouring order. Garlicky mushrooms served in a rather dry flatbread was so-so tasty, but no more than you'd expect from a student dinner party. For me, a duff note came with another student standby, sparse handful of garlic prawns, part shelled, in an insipid tomato and bean sauce. More positive notes came with thick slices of pork belly, tenderly braised and meltingly sweet with hazelnuts and the edge of radicchio. Mackerel tartare is a favourite on the menu, winter and summer, cut through with a horseradish cream, it's a pleasing combination and provides contrast to the meatier dishes. Their polpetta, gamey and (slightly too) salty meatballs are great winter beer fodder but not too sophisticated. The duck ragu was another welcome winter warmer, served with wormlike fingers of strozzapetti pasta and the bite of green peppercorns. Not 'posh nosh' as such, but simple and pleasing.
