lUK3OvSC4btZqL9gEqf9Xg.text: it has gone downhill... VERY fast.nothing was tasty... didn't even compare to what it was 2 years ago.VERY dissappointed... hope you make a comeback polpo...

jeaOEFFMg_vIvTffZZTJaA.text: I should've heeded the negative reviews which were spot on - it's like the kitchen doesn't taste the food! The place is all hype and no flavor...tasteless, soggy calamari, tasteless spinach and egg pizzas, tasteless, still cool in the center meatballs, etc. Disappointing, especially for the price and what could have been an interesting Italian tapas style menu. At least the service is friendly! SKIP.

qThU-_61Oq_Spn6Og0apAg.text: Beer before liquor, never been sicker... but gin before tapas, someone should stop us !Post-elite-eventing tapas ordering was a bit of a whirlwind (this has nothing to do with sickness, just the rhyming!). We ordered something off of every section and had the table absolutely covered from asparagus to calamari with some breads, cheeses and meats thrown in for good measure. Best tapas I've had in quite some time, the common comment was everyone telling each other to try whatever was in front of them at the moment. you won't leave hungry and you won't likely make a bad choice.Amazing, I'm back on the tapas bandwagon. (I was off it for quite some time!)

_fsLH1cmo_UvTC3vlc8wYQ.text: After the success of Sputino we were a bit disappointed with Polpo.  Really nothing special in terms of flavours , expensive for what it is.  But good luck to them for taking advantage of the trend for small plates... London is the best place to do it seeing as you can charge as much for a small plate as a regular sized plate, get some nice decor and average food will be ok.

4P4iy5PAlsOYOsM2KQHxCw.text: I spotted this place one night after attending an elite event hosted by Yelp (thanks- it was very cool). I have heard that it is very hard to find a table there, and I love a challengegot in asked for a place to eat, was told it is going to be 45 minutes wait!!! it is a challenge; I will wait - luckily there was a stool behind the bar to sit on and wait after that fairly long introduction, I have to say that they food was disappointingand the service was kind of ...... in a hurry- waiters don't have time for your questions (if you need to ask about a platter or so)I was happy I finally got a table there but don't remember eating there fondly nothing special and won't be going there again

48IXiVv2SYZ0C0QjJMJ_dA.text: When we were last in London, Beak Street's Polpo was one of the year's big openings. A little while later it was joined by Polpetto (also in Soho), situated above The French House on Dean Street.Inspired by the osterie of Venice both continue to serve rustic food and aperitifs that you would expect to find in Italy - simple, good food and drink - plus a great bustling atmosphere that promises to bring a ray of light to dull winter days.For prices - Just as 1/3 and that will convert to AUD$Look how cheap it is!Sitting at the bar at Polpo a few years later, we were reminded of how much we have missed a proper plate of tapas-style food. Melbourne, and Australia in general, thinks it knows how to do rustic Euro fare, but too much effort and too many flourishes often lead to stripped back yet over-complicated food. And really, if the ingredients and flavour combinations are good, the dazzle should come naturally.Bare walls, small seating area, patrons dining at the bar, no fuss and no modern design. We sipped an Old Fashioned and 250ml carafe of red wine.......and nibbled on anchovy and chickpea crostini, roast pumpkin, parma ham and ricotta salata and pork belly, radicchio and hazelnut soaking in a tasty gravy.As hard as it was to walk away from the intimate interior (I had my eyes set on a bit of an all-day drinking session), we stumbled on to the Jewish deli opened (by the same group) at the end of 2011 to rapturous excitement.Follow: @shark4fishchip

eIkzyJ_rKr7IZwKN8QAhAw.text: Been to almost every Polpo in London, simply because I love it so much! I love the whole small dishes sharing everything style, and every bite is f***ing awesome. Seriously. The only thing that I would complain about is that it's always pretty loud volume, making it hard to carry on a conversation.

Rl5-V6qksWmVcl62DzjZWg.text: I had an absolutely wonderful meal there on Tuesday night with a very good friend of mine. We had Arancini, and the Pizetta, but we had spinach, egg and cheese on ours and my goodness it was to die for. I would have stepped over my own mother for a mouthful of that. We also had some of the Bigoli, some steak, rabbit terrine and for me the best cake ever. It was the flourless orange cake and my god it was the best cake I have ever eaten. Light yet so moist I could have eaten that by the bucketload. I really loved the rustic charm, very friendly service and delightful food. I shall be going back as much as I can. The only annoyance is that you can't book a table in the evening but you can't have it all I suppose!

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom

EVImhvvi-3a2plxowEJZeg.text: Polpo is an Italian restaurant that serves tapas style portions in a minimalist, dark setting in Soho.   I had been here three years ago or so and really enjoyed it.  It certainly has taken a turn for the worse; hopefully I just came here on an off day.The house red was pretty good and not expensive, but most of the food was borderline awful.The positives:Arancini and croquettes - these were well-executed but really how do you mess these up?The negatives:Everything else, food related.  It is clear the kitchen is not tasting the food prior to plating.  There is no chance they have tried this food prior to serving it unless they do not have taste buds.  In general, the food was extremely bland (and I am a fan of subtle flavors) and poorly executed.Meatballs - bland, tasted like mediocre meatballs from any generic Italian-American restaurant.  No real seasoning, no real bite to the meatballs.Frito misto - rubbery squid, too much batter, totally bland.  Really disappointing.Wild mushroom Pizetta - Bland, bad dough, mushrooms were OK.  Speck / pumpkin - Probably the best of the four but still flavorless, other than the speck, which the restaurant did not make.The service was fine, nothing special, but not offensive.  I told the waitress that the food was poor and they knocked off a few items off the bill, which was nice, but that wasn't my objective - I just informed her that the restaurant has taken a turn for the worse.   Extremely disappointing, especially for the cost.

nyHpLGcAYJF2Rw5qcrj8QA.text: My friend and i shared the meatballs was perfectly spiced, the dessert is something you must not miss out on. I loved that they take reservations for lunch but you can walk in for dinner. Great atmosphere and lovely staff.

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Hot chocolate with esse biscuits

gJLhImfsY7Ltr_krYFFd6g.text: I was in London on business when I met some old friends here for dinner. Beautiful atmosphere, great food and wonderful service. Told my friends back here in NY that when they go visit this place is a must

DCv_HVpPtUv93rsoWbiZPA.text: Simple, delicious Venetian small-plates and wine & cocktail offerings in various expertly delivered venues in Central and West London where everything as well as the menu has been considered from temp to lighting to playlist. You could easily while away your afternoon into evening here.

1m7uUuN2oiOEu5NAUzUyhQ.text: Great atmosphere! The octopus and Lamb with pistachio meatballs were great! News to go early because it fills up quickly in the evening!

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom

dn8Co1JBJnwxvcyuF17Myg.text: Oh Polpo, I wanted so much more from you. I got the gist of things: a trendy joint serving Greek-leaning Mediterranean food in tapas portions with good ingredients.I was expecting clean flavours, a focus on top-notch ingredients, and simple food, simply presented so that the individual components could shine.Alas, not so much.All our dishes fell into the category of bland to the point of sadness. I'm all for not messing up a stellar ingredient, but the ingredients weren't stellar: if you want to not season your fennel at all, you best be sure that fennel is at its prime, that your olive oil is brilliantly flavourful, that the cheese you grate over it has presence. Otherwise you end up with a sad, vaguely fennel-y plate of tough white greenage and pale, oily disappointment.The mixed fried seafood dish wasn't seasoned, either: the batter was clunky, the whitebait overwhelmed the other components, and it all cried for a bit of salt, at the very least.I think it's a bit sad but telling that I can't actually recall what else we had, even though we had about seven dishes in all. That's seriously underwhelming.The one dish that did stand out, for the wrong reasons, was the sliced steak salad: contrary to the "thou shalt not touch thine spice rack", this was salted to the point of being inedible.Overall, we left feeling as though we'd dropped far too much money on bland, uninspired tapas composed of bland, flavourless ingredients. What a waste of a good concept.

_M1_eRmrrdnHZKuwmCP_8Q.text: This is undoubtedly one of my favourite restaurants in London. It too is so economically agreeable it tenders ample ground to revisit again and again. The food is absolutely delectable, especially the unforgettable Arancini (so good I purchased the Polpo cookbook solely just to have this recipe). The atmosphere is effortlessly fun and the place never fails to excite. However, on more than one occasion after work it has failed us to get a table. The restaurant (like many now in London adhering to this trend) works on a first-come-first served basis hence during the dinner rush this could mean an hour plus wait for a table. However when you do nab one the service, food and ambience are first class.

sDiPCytSDyrI9ZzDCEsOBg.text: We went here as a group on a Tuesday night, but it was surprisingly busy. The downstairs bar waiting area was understaffed, so we only managed to have one round, despite being there almost an hour. The menu has a good range, although it would be great if they could indicate vegetarian options. The fritto misto definitely needs some sort of sauce, although dips could make a nice improvement for most of the small plates. Staffing problems continued upstairs. Despite asking to order more plates, the waitress never returned and the table was bussed, essentially preventing us ordering more food. Dessert spoons were in very short supply, and the bill was a challenge to get!

fjgXj2CesEgrpgbYNhd7fA.text: A fun midweek place to go for a trendy bite to eat.You can't make reservations, so we got there before 18:30 and even at that time they could only seat us at the bar. This suited us fine, and so we took our pews and scanned through the medium sized menu.I think there were probably more options on the cocktail menu than the food menu! I opted for a refreshing, and strong elderflower martini. It packed a punch and was delightful. Just what I needed on a Thursday evening.The idea of this Venetian style of dining is to pick 2-3 small plates each and share. We opted for veal and porchini meatballs, a lamb dish, goats cheese and salami calzone, a courgette and rocket dish (the waiter recommended we have some veg!), and clam linguine.The calzone was amazing. I don't ever have pizza, but the combination of the goats cheese and salami was great! The clam linguine was as good as any I've had in Italy, the lamb very tender and the meat balls were tasty too.All in all a very good dining experience.The staff were friendly, the bar tender very helpful when we were asking about the number of dishes we should have. The large bottle of tap water served as soon as we sat down was most welcomed. The buzz in the restaurant was nice, busy but not so noisy that you couldn't hear your date. Low level lighting creating a cool evening atmosphere.As we left we noticed a few people queuing outside, so if you're planning on eating there, try and get there early.We paid about £45 for 5 dishes and 2 cocktails. It was more than enough food and the cocktails were strong and delicious.A very nice place to eat!

u1ufo4IU4Dtco33R0KT3gw.text: What an absolutely devine surprise this little restaurant was. We had a wonderful late lunch at Polpo in Soho. We were a table of four and chose to share around six dishes, which we initially thought mightn't be enough, however we ended up having to walk off our lunch in Hyde Park later!They are famous for their meat balls and I can totally see why. We ordered the classic and the spicy pork and fennel which were outstanding. Paired with a salad of rocket and courgette, cold meats with mozzarella and watercress, a selection of the tasting plates and a pizzette we had more than enough to eat.The staff are fantastic and the decor is perfection. I'll definitely be stopping here again.Do make sure you make a reservation as they are extremely busy, we waited half an hour, but chose to have a wander around Liberty while we waited.

55yz8f2d2b251afjJnPLhA.text: When I visited my American friends who live in London, we just had to check out this trendy spot. I was very satisfied with our meal, although we all felt that the service was a bit slow.I ordered the shrimp and asparagus risotto. It was very tasty and surprisingly filling. And for only 7.50, it was well worth it! We also ordered the Mozzarella in carrozza, which we thought was going to be bread covered with melted cheese. It ended up looking and tasting like fried mozarella cheese sticks, so although it wasn't exactly what we were expecting, it was still delicious. The house red wine was also tasty and reasonably priced. My friends definitely plan on going back, and if I weren't just passing through, I'm sure I'd do the same.

S7cWwes27auLydq7pSGzNw.text: I've heard amazing things about Polpo and been meaning to go there for ages. Well, last Friday I had the pleasure of dining at Polpo. Except, it was actually really disappointing. The ambience is great, the atmosphere is nice, the service is quick and friendly, but the food - awful. We ordered 5 plates of food (it's essentially a tapas place so you'll have to mix and match) and by the end of it, the waiters collected 4 plates of half finished meals. The focaccia bread was the saltiest thing I've had in years, the market greens turned out to be a plate of boiled kale (in its defence, the kale was lovely while it was warm), prawn tagliatelle was swimming in fat and the risotto had peas so minty that it was inedible. What upsets me the most is not the fact we bought five plates of below mediocre food, but the fact I've been planning on going there for ages and when the opportunity presented itself (Polpo was still open at 10.30pm), it was an utter disappointment.Soho offers everything and anything a foodie could ask for, but sadly, Polpo is not what a foodie would want. If you're after Italian-esque tapas, check out Sountino instead.

xrF9K3g6ZQm7DqdVJpgs4A.text: It was not BAD, but the hype around it is not legitimateI had the probably most expensive meatballs in tomato sauce that exist, but to be fair, it was excellent meatballs. I cannot argue the quality. I read in some reviews that people complain about food being bland. I cannot completely agree to that. I myself greatly enjoy spicy food and a good mix of seasoning. But Polpo just does minimal seasoning. That is a style and it is made with lots of thought. The meat had a great taste and needed only a minimal amount of salt and herbs. It played out very well. The orange almond cake made a great impression on me. I loved it very much. If the food was so good, why not at least one more star? I am surprised that this is supposed to be a rare food experience in London? Are there not a good dozen more Italian restaurants, who can deliver that quality? There is a hype that creates a crowd of waiting people. And the place probably does not deserve that much hype.

StYPOgUInpbpHtOaCZG6iA.text: I love Polpo. It's one of my regular Soho dining spots - affordable good food and great atmosphere (reminds me of hipster New York). The cichettis are so tasty - my favourites are the chickpea/anchovy and chicken liver crostinis. If you don't like anchovies, I definitely wouldn't recommend ordering it because the smell and taste of it is quite strong! The fritto misto is another favourite of mine - fried but not greasy selection of calamari, fish, octopus etc...yum! The spinach/parmesan/poached egg pizzette is sooooo good - probably my favourite dish  from Polpo. The meatballs are also very good. For dessert I'd highly recommend the ricotta/chocolate crumble - super rich but delicious.Service is friendly and prompt. Polpo's a perfect night out with friends for a quick bite or a casual dinner...not to mention they have a good selection of cocktails/wine! Only down side is that it gets very very busy so I find myself having to eat early if I don't want to queue (and why I hesitate to give it 5 stars). They do take bookings for lunch though which is a consolation!

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom

tXmbe-Gdmu86wqRUeEsnNQ.text: Food was decent, some items more memorable than others.1. Grilled fennel and white anchovy CICHETI - 2 stars2. Baccala mantecato crostini - 4 stars!3. Lamb & mint meatballs - 3 stars4. Braised scallops, pancetta & peas - 3 stars5. Chilli & garlic prawns - 3 stars6. Rabbit & chicory tonnata salad - 2 stars7. Zucchini, rocket, Parmesan - 4 stars!Wine selection was decent as well but I didn't feel it was memorable.Would I return if friends wanted? YesWould I return by my own choice?  No but that's cause there are so many places I haven't tried yet in London.

-Ye2AArYgHLL-6DnEz7J8g.text: On a previous visit to London I didn't make it to Polpo... for my latest trip I was determined to add it to my itinerary - what I experienced was some good eats and bad service.We were told 45 minutes was the wait but we were seated 1.5 hrs later. The no-res policy is just stupid, btw. What year is this? The bar staff downstairs was delightful, as were the cocktails - best part of the evening.The folks running the front of house are amateurs - plain and simple. They didn't ask how they could make it up to us or offer even a free drink or dessert to make up for the painfully long wait. Instead they chose to rush us our food minutes after we ordered... we had no time to savor the wine before every plate hit the table at once. Sloppy service, indeed. The food was fine. The duck ragu, fennel salad, classic meatballs were all solid. The pork belly was dry and uninteresting. We ordered the fried olives but like our server they never appeared at the table... The standouts oddly were the grilled bread and mini canolli. I'd go back for the Campari bar and the delightful folks and drinks but would pass on the dining room Bocca Di Lupo is a far better choice for food.

phKDTaBwMjeA4bqTsQUc3Q.text: Excellent food, drinks, atmosphere! Stopped in before going to see Les Miserables with some friends and it was perfect!

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Fabulous cocktails

_OYVjqoGXJSQ8qL_3wn1XQ.text: This restaurant was totally meh. It came highly recommended by a friend, and I was given a list of 10 other restaurants to choose from for dinner, but I ended up picking this one based on the menu. I came in excited to try the food, but left SUPER disappointed. The food was incredibly bland and flavorless. The mushroom pizza came out cold. It was dry and tasteless, the ratios were all off. The spaghetti and meatballs we ordered tasted like they were frozen and heated in a microwave. The pumpkin with cheese and spec was also disappointing. I finished the meal feeling unsatisfied and ripped off. On the walk back to my hotel through Chinatown, I found myself wishing I'd eating at a $5 Chinese buffet instead, it was that bad.This restaurant may have ruined my friendship with my friend too, since I had SUCH high hopes going in only to be sorely disappointed by it's below averageness. Don't make the same mistake.

sq-7Ihp9fks_Q6jhCGdHeQ.text: Finally ate at the first Polpo (I went to Polpetto when it was open, have been to the Covent Garden locale, drop in to Mishkins from time to time and am in love with Spuntino.)  This location always seems to be the busiest.  Well, only a 2 hour wait on a Friday at 7:30 (although we did get seated at 9).  And we had to wait at the bar downstairs--and it was hot down there.  Limited munchies menu for the downstairs and I must say not very exciting.  As always though, the pizzettas were great, the meatballs delicious, and the combinations and flavors interesting and exciting.  But most of all I like the atmosphere--the place has a good vibe.I am a fan of this group of restaurants--always have been and always will be.  Nothing to blow you away, but good food and good atmosphere is worth the wait.

ZfhnTT0n0iPneX7gi24KkA.text: I like this place a lot.It is a popular venue, as others have mentioned, and you may have to wait for a while to get your table. That said there is a Campari bar downstairs or it may be possible to enjoy your beverage street-side by the window as we did.The ingredients are well balanced and provide an interesting mix of flavours. The zucchini, chilli and mint pizette is delicious for example.My partner said the sliced flank steak was "incredible" and I can testify that the flourless orange and almond cake was damn good.Give it a go, but leave work 30 minutes early and beat the rush!

hyAV4m-BI1lqc6dsqQMNLg.text: First date... come here. Drinks with friends... come here... Want to eat a delicious meal.. don't come here and this is why. This ambiance is great, that of a happening, busy, and hip wine bar and tapas joint. The Gin Fizz I had was ok.. a bit medicinal tasting but hey after a couple sips I stopped caring so much. My friend and I shared a few plates:*Braised* Scallops, pancetta and Peas under the fish section. - here's a definition of  braised, brais*ing.to cook (meat, fish, or vegetables) by sautéeing in fat and then simmering in a small amount of liquid in a covered pot.  They do not know the meaning of Braise AT ALL. What we got was a soup. When I asked the server about this dish, and that i was expecting NOT a soup he said.. yeah, thats just how they serve it here. -Prawn & Asparagus risotto. It was decent, subtle and tasting of the sea. -The Calfs Liver and Onions and Sage.- Sage? What sage. The Calfs liver was ok, mineral tasting, and actually our least favorite dish. The onions were nicely sautéed and sweet. -The Goat cheese & Nettle pesto Piadina was BOMB. HOLY SHIT GOOD. Freshly baked bread with a thick schmear of goats cheese in the center topped with a deliciously garlicky pesto paste. It was the highlight of the meal. Desserts- The Amalfi Lemon and Yoghurt Fool - Delicous. Simple yoghurt dish with crunchy sweet biscuits crumbled on top and hidden at the bottom. - Flourless orange and almond cake - gorgeous cake smothered in a rich sweet sauce topped with candied orange slices. So, why do i think its perfect for a date. Because you won't want to stuff yourself first off, you have a wide array of drink possibilites to lubricate conversation and the desserts are great!

CVjCJFvWzHTPlz57Mmd15w.text: Slightly cramped surroundings but delicious food does make up for it. Hard to get a gauge of the number of dishes you need and I'm not sure I believe the amount the servers recommend - I honestly think that would have been way too much food. What I did have - a special gnocchi with blue cheese and meatballs - was delicious and my friend's focaccia especially looked fantastic.Our server was lovely, if a little haphazard, but there did seem to be a bunch of staff members who acted a little too cool for their job. I know it's Soho guys and so painfully cool (*rolls eyes*) but you still have to tell me where the bathrooms are....

ye0X6tRqInoQLCmXEs-Zbg.text: Great ambiance, mediocre service and food.We walked in Polpo after a long day of walking around the city. The interior and menu looked great so we took a small table inside. Our server recommended getting two plates each to share them all. She also said they would come out whenever they were ready, instead of all at once.We ordered the risotto balls--these were fried and cheesy inside but very small! We then got the beef meatballs in sauce. These were about four meatballs in a red sauce. They were tasty but not outstanding. We then got the broccoli with hazelnuts. The broccoli was a bit under-cooked and didn't have enough flavor.The service at this restaurant was a bit confusing. It seems the servers help all the tables, instead of being assigned specific parties. We asked four servers for our check and kept waiting for it to arrive! It was very odd and we couldn't understand why this took so long after so many people asked us if we wanted anything else.I would say the price and ambiance here doesn't match the quality and service. Very underwhelming.

6--V9VAq4jJSwFGy4gDFxg.text: Polpo specializes in small Italian plates, so it's recommended to order a bunch and share with friends. Around 2-3 plates per person should suffice. It's quite the trendy restaurant, so the dining room often gets packed. The spinach pipette was pretty good, but everything else that we ordered was just ok. Not really worth queueing up for.

-KDDc49zVpSyMCw6FxUUBA.text: Entirely under-whelming. Was hoping to enjoy grilled octopus - it's out of season, as I found out. Was pointed to meatballs that their 'known for' - about as bland as frozen. Potato and parm cheese croquettes were equally 'good'.  Left most of it all uneaten.  Oh well. Just proof that bland food exists everywhere.

4EisdaZ0a9-VzB8tq6_Jsw.text: We gave the Polpo two tries. Our first visit was on new years eve and we just wanted to have drinks and snacks at the bar. The waiters were really rude and we didn't feel welcome at all. But as Polpo is highly recommended in the travel guides we gave it another try and came back for dinner the following evening. The food was ok but nothing more. I had a gorgonzola/ham Pizza and it didn't contain gorgonzola at all. It was loaded with much to much cheese but not with the one announced. The Radicchio/Sellery/Apple/Pecorino Salad was much to sour (I think the dressing was just vineagar) and the Pecorino was arranged like Gold Dust (Nearly not existing). The wine wasn't good at all. There are better places to eat in London!

4tjthf0bIIb4gMLzJSUBIg.text: Solid small plate style Italian. Tasty all round, I recommend the chilli and crab linguine. Great wine options although served in shitty tumblers.

UsdMSMJWOO5pPcAZyKxqeA.text: Wonderful, cozy place to enjoy small bites and delicious wine!  Perfect with a group of friends who are up for sharing great food and conversation.  My friends and I went in for a late lunch and ended up staying for over three hours.

4U5xf2AfUYEWaLWag_KT5A.text: EN: It's a nice, little place in SoHo with decent food but nothing I would go out of my way to eat. It does seem to be trendy and full of people, though. I had the fennel salami and ricotta pizza and although it's small it is quite filling. SP: Un lugar bastante agradable en SoHo con buena comida pero nada fuera de este mundo. Aunque la comida no sea increíble, parece ser un restaurante muy trendy con mucha gente. Pedí la pizzette de salami y ricotta, es chica pero si te llena.

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom

_uvy5uijGtpMRbx_fEiC3w.text: Lovely location and ambiance. The food was delicious as well. From the pizzas to the meatballs, we enjoyed everything we ordered so much that we went twice during our five day visit in London. It is a tapas style restaurant which is perfect for sharing and trying new items on the menu. It was recommended to us by two different friends who used to live in London and it did not disappoint.

dWGlUJPeP3gXefK2Crfa3w.text: The restaurant serves Venetian food in small, tapas plates. Our orders came with two arancini, three meatballs, and so on. It's easy to get carried away with one of everything (and then one or two extra when you find something you like). A friend and I shared a variety of small plates. They recommend 2-3 per person. The arancini were my favorite - unbelievably creamy inside a golden crust. I also loved the meatballs "alla Vedova" which were rolled in polenta (no sauce).  The regular meatballs in marinara were flavorful. Even the bread was delicious - coated in olive oil, grilled, and dusted with sea salt. The special du jour risotto with rocket was WAY too salty. I could have skipped the mushroom piadina. We tried a few of the mixed drinks and they were great. The gin fizz was a sweet mix of gin and prosecco. And the dark and stormy used a spicy ginger beer. This is one of a few locations in London. I'll definitely be back next time I'm the city.

cpotx1xZIzWQgxSuCk7cFQ.text: Heard lots of great buzz around this place but don't think it quite lives up to the hype. It has potential but there is a lot of places I would go first. The downstairs bar that you can wait in is a great idea especially as this is a 'no bookings' restaurant. You can order starters down here but the starters aren't too flash. We ordered the crab arancini and stuffed olives. They came out on the same plate: no garnish, no sauces, no love (see my picture). The olives tasted ok.When we were taken upstairs for our table we sat at our table for 30mins before getting even a menu. We weren't in a hurry so we would have preferred to stay downstairs and get our own drinks. We ended up grabbing the drinks menu for ourselves (and we also grabbed water for ourselves too) Anyway bad service. A lot of attitude coming from staff. We were a whole table of hospitality people so always understand if it's busy but they were plain disinterested in service and more interested chatting to themselves. We ordered drinks. Then some more sharing things and some medium plates which all seemed to come out at once. And the wine came out after the food (I think they forgot to put our order in). Again simple apology or sincerity would have been fine but we inconvenienced the waitress by asking her twice. The octopus was lovely. A little cold but tasty. The mackerel tartare turned out to be salmon, not fresh. I can't remember the other dish we ordered but whatever it was supposed to be was over powered with a lot of olive tapenade and mustard on very very stale bread that we couldn't cut through. There was also some soggy deep-fried fish. At that point we asked for the bill and we to a much better place around the corner. So yeah go to a lovely french place around the corner.

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom. The crab aranchini balls and crumbed olives. Obvs a garnish shortage in Soho.

cyqkDYAA_Q1hfmfOIdl9GA.text: A gem in London! The food is excellent with exciting and interesting flavors. Having lived in Chicago for four years (America's food capital), it was refreshing finding such great food for reasonable prices in London.I dined here with three others and our server recommended we get 2-3 plates per person. It was a good amount and we left very happy and satisfied. I highly recommend the Flank Steak, Grilled Lamb, Linguine Vongole, and the Chickpea Meatballs.Make sure to save room for dessert! The flourless orange and almond cake, and the Nutella Pizette are divine!Come here hungry!

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Nutella pizzette!
Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Flourless orange and almond cake
Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Chickpea, spinach and ricotta Meatballs

Y0pKeP_6rqn9w9yU5bw7JQ.text: Great atmosphere and selection of tapas! A nice spot to duck into when out on the town.

zmhoXrN1mzIynK2kEJ6P5A.text: A place where you go and wait to seat in a very uncomfortable seat, with no back support and high tables. It's noisy, so you can't talk with your friends without yelling. Therefore, you all stare at each other while a waiter comes with a menu. Prices are promisingly cheap, but the waiter says you have to share dishes.So you ask two dishes, stuffed olives and a mushroom risotto. It's all very good, but portions are tiny. I don't mean tiny for Italian standards (I know we can overreact on our portions sometimes...), I mean tiny for French standards. To make it clearer: I have paid 4 pounds for the stuffed olives portion. A portion comprised of *three* olives. (very good ones, but still...)Time to pay. One of your friends mistakes a fiver for a tenner. The manager comes and almost yells at him - "there are five pounds missing, figure it out". Your friend laughs nervously. You and your friends go home a bit hungry, with £20 less in your pockets, and you wonder if you should buy a cheap pizza in a truly Italian place on the way home.At least it's not that noisy in the streets, so you can chat with your friends for the first time tonight.

oIV3qERK9TmmHtDnk5_cww.text: Fabulous breadcrumbed oliveFood is tapas style and very niceAtmosphere is casual and warm. Good quality but a bit pricey. The fact you can find plenty of Italian cocktails and alcohols is really cool

k6xraCROpR0AraegTg9g2Q.text: I'm not the biggest fan of queuing restaurants, on arrival we were greeted by a member of staff and informed us that it would be 30-40 minutes wait for a table. We got to wait in the basement bar for our table, but it was a bit small we were lucky enough to get a seat but as we waited more people started to arrive.  We ordered two pear and fennel juices from the bar which sounded interested, but I was disappointed to find out it was a prepared juice in a bottle and it tasted a bit bland and watery. After 35 minutes we were taken to a table upstairs, the lighting was low and the atmosphere was bustling with low level music playing. We placed our order of 6 tapas dishes most of the dishes were well presented and tasty, however the lamb and pistachio meatballs were slightly disappointing as I couldn't taste the pistachio. The dessert was also a bit of a let down we had lemon and almond cake, it looked like just a piece of sponge and had only a slight lemon flavour.

smcnWoXMnU7qcI3wHN2P5A.text: Very cramped .... Sitting at the bar table , I got nudged and elbowed many times .... Well the bar people are pretty nice . The meatballs are mediocre . And they do only spaghetti , no fettuccini ...

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom. This one can take up to 30 mins to come . I simply suspect they forgot my order
Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom

0Q1L4gX81TtbAeeK3mO_TA.text: We read quite a bit about this place and it frequently popped up in a lot of the lists of restaurants to go to while visiting London, so we had high expectations of this tapas style eatery. This was our first meal in London and seeing that they did not accept reservations, we arrived promptly at 12pm when it opened and were seated right away. We stuck with the Bianca pizzette, Duck ragu w/ black olives & gnocchi, the Zucchini w/ parmesan & basil, and per our waitress's suggestion, the meatballs "alla vedova". The best plate was the fried meatballs which was crispy on the outside and so savory on the inside. All others were only just okay and not quite that memorable. We really wanted to like the place and wanted to order more, but we left feeling semi-full and slightly disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Meatballs alla Vedova
Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Bianca Pizzette

DhlmdstEVNnIk4dn0jH7zQ.text: Always crowded spot and now I know why--excellent Italian tapas. 4.5 starsFood: 4.5, Service: 3, Atmosphere: 3.5Cost to worth it rating: 4Eve award: best huge bruschetta Return worthiness: yes!Highlights:- Bruchetta: artichokes, prosciutto, and cheese. Best thing we had (and most everything was fantastic).- Spicy clam pizza: sounds odd and didn't know what to expect, but it was awesome. Not fishy with a good amount of spice, fresh sauce, and springy dough- Meatballs: another big hit. Delicious meat mixture and covered in sauce- Pasta: fresh with rich ingredients to coat it- Atmosphere: very livelyLowlights:- Crowded: usually hard to get a table Loved my fun meal here and will for sure be back.

tXQrfT-BtT0TraaOfTTHYg.text: Casual catch up over wine with a friend eventually took us here. We had to wait a little while at the bar to get a seat - very popular, even on a late Monday evening! We were quite hungry so ordered quite a few dishes!! Really really good italian food! Small little plates so definitly need to order a few. Definitly recommend this place - great food and really tasty wine. Cute little italian place with very friendly staff!

sQQWoUuLxvEaULMoo1SnhA.text: Busy, buzzy but the food is a bit mediocre. The atmosphere at Polpo is fantastic and the food is tasty enough, but it just doesn't blow me away. It's reasonably priced though, and there is a good selection of wine by the glass/carafe/bottle.

TyHeuPFe-7_tEne9qYSbUA.text: No chance to sample the food. We were a group of 4 for a birthday party with one additional guest stuck in traffic. Despite our assurance we were not being seated unless as a full group. We left very frustated after 25 min waiting at the bar to go elsewhere. I have never heard of such a policy, certainly not with only one person missing and an essentially empty restaurant. A very disappointing experience and staff in dealing with us.

1Hb0In3_gSbXlTPY3xnpLg.text: Probably the only place in London to have a traditional Venetian Spritz (drink with Aperol or Campari, soda & white wine with a slice of orange or lemon and an olive - yum!) The food and service were also excellent, a must return!

LiN99t9Ihayz_zMGMktWhw.text: [Non-photo review] For full review, please see: wp.me/pwXBH-Jo  Polpo  Sohopeful, So Good Summary:A Venetian bacaro meets Lower East Side Manhattan bar, Polpo has a lovely buzzy atmosphere and relaxed but professional service in the middle of London's Soho. The food is simple, with most dishes employing five ingredients or less, and is executed very well on the whole, with some real standouts. It's also not overly expensive if you can reign yourself in from the tempting offerings. I really wanted to like Polpo, and after two long lunches there, am pleased to say that it is a place I really enjoy being at, and intend to frequent in the future. Getting ready for cicchetti Having just written about another Soho restaurant that offers good value for money, I am happy to be scribbling about another one which I recently discovered. Somewhat to my surprise, I was not the last London food blogger to visit the rather new and ever-popular Polpo. Indeed, it appeared that a twitter 'friend' I had communicated with virtually for some time had also not been (I know, the travesty), and it seemed like an apt time and place for a lunch with @KaveyF, the woman behind Kavey Eats. I had a lot of preconceived notions and high expectations about this place. Firstly, the response from bloggers that I generally tend to agree with had been decidedly mixed. Secondly, having been to Venice a number of times and understanding the bacari that Polpo presumably purports itself to be modelled after, I was cynical about how well they would be able to carry out this concept in central London, without the ethereal magic of the Venetian canals and architecture. (As a side note, it is quite a neat coincidence that Polpo does happen to sit right beneath the plaque marking the spot where Canaletto, the Venetian painter, lived in London). There are very few places in London that offer proper cicchetti (pronounced 'chi-ket-ee'), and I went to one just after starting this blog, which was a posher incarnation of the concept but wasn't half bad (just a bit pricey). At their heart, cicchetti are very small plates of simple food that Venetians typically have from anytime in the very late morning through to mid-to-late afternoon at local bars (bacari), and they are normally accompanied by a small glass of wine. From my own experience, they are typically eaten at the bar standing up, or possibly on a stool or outside the bacaro if it is a warm day, maybe overlooking the canal. In fact, the icon that I use for my online avatar is the shop-front of a very nice little bacaro that I happened upon while staying in the relatively quiet and peaceful Accademia neighborhood on my last visit to Venice. It's mostly frequented by locals and is quite traditional. They sell wine on a retail basis, offer some by the glass and a range of snacks to eat with the small glasses of wine they serve. I love the whole concept and ethos of snacking in Venice, so was hoping that Polpo wouldn't screw around with the simple and successful formula too much. Polpo's proprietor, Russell Norman, was formerly Operations Director at Caprice Holdings (Richard Caring's dining empire, which continues to expand rapidlyand internationally as of late) and, as such, has a lot of experiencing opening new restaurants and making them successful. He says that his two main inspirations for the restaurant were the bacari of Venice and Manhattan's Lower East Side, Tribeca and Soho, where he saw a particular type of place to eat and socialize that didn't exist in London. The place certainly opened with a bang, and much was made of Russell's proactive use of twitter right through the time leading up to the opening, and then during the eventual launch of the restaurant. Despite the reservations of some bloggers and critics, I was still excited to see what the place would be like, especially after having looked through the window many times on visits to other nearby haunts  one of my current favorite hang-outs in London is Bob Bob Ricard, which is literally just across the narrow Beak street. Made for Manhattan? I arrived at Polpo just about on time, as is my wont. Kavey had already arrived, though, and it turned out she had come prepared. Now I don't just mean that she had read a few blog posts, reviews and looked at the online menu and therefore had a good idea of what she might want to order. No, the girl had a very large Excel spreadsheet in a very small font size which cross-referenced the dishes on the website ample menu against what some of her trusted bloggers thought of each dish. I was impressed, but also slightly scared and we had a good chuckle over itbut it did prove very useful. The menus were the place-mats, so we didn't have to undergo the often annoying wait for menus to be given and explained to us. And I have to say, it all sounded very appetizing. We asked our lovely waitress how many dishes she recommended ordering and I was slightly surprised at the number of dishes she

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom

mkQvZ1lm__HumjMS7_4WLA.text: We loved Polpo! It was a special celebration lunch for our little family and obviously I ahd not booked in advance... Lunch gets busy there so do come early or get lucky which is what happened to us. In any event if you are just 2 the wait shouldnt be too long and you can waith drinking a campari or other Italian aperitivo (4GPB). We sat at the bar with our 2 young kids on our knees and had a blast. The staff was really nice, casual but pro, and took good care of us, not many Italians though. There is a good vibe in this lively restaurant, so do not go if you want a quiet, formal lunch or dinner, but do go if you want the buzz of the city mixed with a relaxed, relaxed Italian-style place. Polpo is supposed to look and feel like a Venetian trattoria, they mostly manage this but the best part is the food. Tapas-style cicchetti plates are really great as you can try so many different tastes while keeping your bill to a reasonable level and leave feeling full enough. We loved everything, the crochette, the pumpkin risotto, the wet polenta, the steak with mushroom and ruccola (the best!), the fritto misto, the gelatto and finallly the simply perfect expresso. We had a san giovese wine with this and a 65 pounds bill. We are looking forward to try at night, wish there were more good and simple places like this in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Polpo - Soho - London, United Kingdom

jk8uJocoxIrIPz65xLSZOQ.text: Undoubtedly, the atmosphere, warmth and buzz are the best thing about this newcomer. It is great to see the addition of cicchetti to the ever growing roster of "tapas" of the world - don't get me wrong - I just wish they were tastier. The food was good, but not great, and at £20 a head for a sufficient number of plates, dessert and a couple of beers, it's not a bad night out. The arancini, made with rice, peas and mozzarella were nice. Their croquette cousins were a bit bland, but the batter for both was excellent. The mackerel on polenta - tasteless and greasy. The fritto misto - avoid. It was surprisingly devoid of flavour, limp and must have been fried well before it was served. The cuttlefish with ink gremolata was unusual and quite tasty as was the pizzetta bianca. The pork belly with hazel nuts and radicchio was well presented and adequately tasty. Unlike the savouries, the desserts were all very good. The dense and creamy hot chocolate was perfect for the cold evening. The nut and honey semifreddo (ice cream cone served in a glass) was delicious, as was the flourless orange and almond cake. Overall, I enjoyed the evening and I would return because the atmosphere was good.

yEz9OmGfO2UvC4CofpJwvw.text: We went Polpo for a work colleague's leaving dinner; there was 8 us in total on the recommendation of from a friend who knew the owner of restaurant. I found the venue to be really small and very cramped; too noisy I could hardly hear what the other guests at our table were talking about. The food was nice although I found the menu to limited in choice and variety; I only eat fish or the vegetarian options on a menu. Disappointed by the dessert menu, I did expect something better. The wine was pretty average and nothing special. Overall we each paid £45 per head including food and wine I would say it wasn't worth the money spent. And would I go again? Honestly, I probably won't.

3sCjaSn2rOuxpmw2NZ-BAw.text: Polpo is a Venetian 'bacaro' with a New York vibe on the former Soho premises of Aperitivo, from ex-Caprice Holdings director Russell Norman. Polpo has a no reservation policy for dinner, so expect to queue, as this place is currently very popular, and deservedly so.

-LDMLHSc5wydZ7a93GSM2Q.text: We squeezed in here last night, without a booking. Staff very friendly but still finding their feet  drinks took a while to arrive and one side dish never appeared (though we didn't hassle them for it). Reasonable value for the area  we paid just over £100 for two including service (built in to the bill). We had four smaller dishes, five larger ones, two deserts, two coffees and a litre of wine. Several wines available in 500ml carafes, which we appreciated. We seemed to have a preponderance of ham, but that was probably our fault and not a bad thing in my view. Food generally good. Highpoints were a sort of ham sandwich with tomato (sorry for poor description). Low point was a bland wet polenta  texturally unexciting.

CWhVEretq7IoqPl9mn8eHQ.text: There are very very few Italian restaurants that make this half italian woman nostalgic for 'real' italian food, not just by name but by very the nature of the cooking and Polpo managed to do just this. A scruffy dining room that somehow, desipite distressed walls...that is truly distressed not designer distressed manages to be welcoming, buzzy, fun and 'foodie serious' all at the same time. We were seated by the owner, the lovely tousled haired Russell (also owns Boca di lupo) and immediately felt we were part of a 'secret' club, every single diner had a smug...'look at me arnt I lucky look on their face', given the q for tables, that wasn't surprising. The presmise of the food is Venetian Tapas, or cichetti as they're known in Italy and if that sounds faddy....well it's not...tiny potato croquettes, crisy on the outside melting in the middle arrived alongside a selection of other dishes priced between £3-£6 that were really really good and tasted somehow of Italy.crostini with wild mushrooms, calamari fritti, grilled vegetables, tiny pork ribs then the best thing i've tasted in a long long time arrived.......the meatballs....ohmygod....I am a bit of meatball fiend...love making them and love eating them and in fact considered mine to be the best ever after years of perfecting them...well.....they're not, these are...I urge to go just to taste these little balls of gorgeousness...incredible...moist, well seasoned, soft yet firm in a rich tomato sauce... I could have eaten bowl fulls of them. The bill for 5 dishes, a bottle of water and a glass of house white came £27 for two of us. GO NOW.

WvSYtLQDyi-uhgWHujb4Dw.text: delicious. quick. nice. charming. but a bit on the expensive side. would go again.

ObhXgs-qV56aGJp9dEq3HQ.text: Truth to tell my friend(one of the fourth estate) reccomended this place and since she was paying I did not object. started with camapri and soda(well it a baccaro in Soho) and continued through numerous bottle of white wine and after dinner drinks. Tried about 12 dishes onlt one disappointment trapezzini or somehting like that which turned out to be 2 triangle of ham sandwich on white bread. Although I cannot remember everything eaten standouts were the sprats, proscuitto and fig dish, the duck, the steak and the black ink dish(I have hazy recollections of a fish of some sort being involved). Have no idea what it cost as the fourth estate paid(it pays to be a source) but whatever it was it was worth it for a very pleasnat evening. Tip though we managed to get a table after a not too indecent wait if I were to return I would book a table in advance.

tmM5G3SBl-p3PtFgYuZmiQ.text: Was able to get a table for a late work lunch. I know there's been a lot of hype around this place - both good and bad. I'm not sure why... It's not the best restaurant I've ever been to, but it's certainly not the worst. I quite enjoyed the whole experience. Our server was lovely - very polite. The food we had was mostly very good. Standout for me was the roast pumpkin with prosciutto. Dessert of cake with choclate was just ok, but maybe I just didn't order the right thing. I'll definitely go back. I'm very curious to see how Polpo evolves after all the 'new restaurant hype.

UsHsAnyTmVdCm3E7GKsaEg.text: Recommended by a local. Nice variety but expensive for the portions and location. What you get is not disappointing though. Well prepared and presented. VERY casual.

G4idrygP_Ev8v310c09WwA.text: Polpo - Pics @ The London Foodie(thelondonfoodie.co.uk ) I thought there would be nothing else to add to the media frenzy surrounding Polpo, the new Italian darling and makers of cicheti or small-eats, or tapas or whatever-you-wanna-call-it in Soho. It's been blogged and highly praised by just about every food blogger in London  but after my disappointing meal there last Saturday, I thought I would put pen to paper and dare to differ. First impressions were excellent  the décor was charming, the front-of-house staff very friendly and the place nearly full and buzzing with a beautiful and trendy crowd at 5:45pm. We started the evening by ordering a couple of their breads, White Bean Bruschetta £4 and Wild Mushroom Piadina £4.80, followed by a selection of cicheti and crostini. The white beans had been cooked in rosemary and were very aromatic and perfectly al dente, a good Italian version of beans on toast. The Piadina was similar to a crepe and was filled with fried wild mushrooms. Both breads were nicely prepared although the portions were ludicrously small. We ordered two portions of each, and struggled to share them among the five of us. Our selection of cicheti and crostini included arancini £1.50, anchovy & chick pea crostini £1.10, potato and parmesan croquette £1.20 and salt cod on grilled polenta £2.10. I love Italian baccala (salted cod), and cook it frequently at home  I have made a similar dish of flaked salted cod with parsley, garlic and olive oil over grilled polenta a few times at home. These intensely flavoured ingredients should balance beautifully with the blander polenta, and when well made this dish is truly heavenly. Polpo's version however was very disappointing  the polenta was cold and soggy, and the salted cod completely tasteless. We ordered three pieces and we all agreed they were rather poor. The arancini were tiny and very uninspiring, and so were the anchovy & chick pea crostini and potato and parmesan croquettes. I tried a bit of each, and struggle to find anything at all to say about them. Completely passable comes to mind. The more substantial meat and fish dishes that we ordered included Slow Roasted Duck £6.10, Calves Liver, Onion and Sage £5.90, Grilled Flank Steak with Mushroom £6.90, and Fritto Misto £6.60. We also ordered a portion of Pork Belly, Radicchio and Hazelnuts @ £5.70 but it never turned up. Two of these dishes were good  the calves liver was well cooked, although not as delicately flavoured and soft as it should have been, while the fritto misto (deep fried whitebait and seafood) was crisp and utterly delicious. The flank steak was beautifully presented but in my opinion lacked seasoning, and the slow roasted duck was unexciting. It was served in a pool of tomato sauce and did not look terribly appetizing. All portions were very ungenerous. To accompany the above we also ordered a portion of Roast Potatoes and Rosemary £3.70, Grilled Polenta £3 and Fennel, Curly Endive and Almonds @ £3.90. These were all well made and flavoursome, but again the portions were minute. For pudding, we had a few Affogato al caffe £2.60 each (vanilla ice cream immersed in espresso coffee), Flourless Orange & Almond Cake £4.40, and Honey & Walnut Semifreddo @ £3.80. The affogato tasted just right - both the ice cream and the coffee were of high quality. The orange and almond cake was light and delicious, and I enjoyed it immensely. I did not try the semifreddo but John seemed impressed with his choice. The wine list was impressive and reasonably priced, with bottles of white and red starting at £15 through to £38. Polpo serves most of its whites and a few reds in 250ml and 500ml measures at no extra cost. A bottle of 750ml will cost £15 while 500ml & 250ml measures will cost £10 and £5 respectively. This is a nice thought, and the flat pricing structure should encourage wine drinkers to try different wine combinations to accompany their cicheti. My dinner companions were old friends from a wine club I used to belong to in Dulwich (Dulwich Wine Society), and therefore our wine choices were good but rather pricey. We had a couple of bottles of Gavi (white) £30 each and two of Barbera (red) £21 each. The total bill came to £208, including service, or £42 per person. The general consensus was that it was a disappointing and expensive meal and some of us were still peckish at the end of it. Verdict  A clear example of style over substance. Good deep fried fish, good desserts, excellent wine list but tiny, ridiculously tiny portions. Some of the dishes were seriously disappointing for a restaurant currently the subject of such hype. I am not planning a return visit.

U1ZA8m6CZrIhqP0QmtADNQ.text: I think this is an incredible little place, fantastic unfussy food, wonderful wines, and you can feel the love in the look of the place and the people who run the place. Loads of review already there but I just wanted to add that the mark of great service is that when they have fully full and booked, they help you with a few recommendations of places nearby for your meal. And that's a exactly what happened to me at Polpo a few weeks back. Now that's what I call service. Just super friendly. My favourite dish so far is the almost melting good cooked sausage with cabbage and mustard, yum!

I5Al00UiIqWyPMZkbKz4uw.text: Lovely little restaurant serving little italian dishes. Enjoyed the food a lot. Would certainly recommend.

1j9ZGk8xygSSnhlG3DeECA.text: Amazing combinations of flavors and texture. Love it. I particularly love the small plates style, so much more to try. Great staff as well.

wuOguP3aLHytK5IQX0TJEw.text: Andrew adviced me this restaurant and I thank him.This restaurant is close to Carnaby Street. It is quite tiny and this gives an typical and good atmosphere. When we went with my girlfriend, it's crowed but we had a table for 2. The menu is detailed. My girlfriend took the grilled steak with mushrooms and me the "bressalla" ( it's slices of beef traditional in Italy). We also took grilled potatoes. It was really good. The staff are really friendly and helpful. They are available for you and are willing to take time for you.Finally the price isn't very expensive and we ate for 2 for only 22£.I advise before to go to reserve a table.

F_AB3SxAzZXJpKHzSSPadQ.text: Well I really liked this place. Being more used to Italian Food from Western and Central Italy, I thought the concept of smaller plates from Veneto complemented by the fantastic wines from the area really worked. The Squid Ink Risotto (around £8) was the real highlight for me- mouthwateringly tasty and pretty filling for those not splashing out too much cash!We had started off in the cute basement bar whilst waiting for a table to come free. The barman knew his wines and found us a bottle that matched the description of what we fancied. We also had some little bites on cocktail sticks- asparagus and taleggio amongst others. Pretty decent sizes for what they cost too. The vibe overall is relaxed and very much in keeping with the Soho setting- bustling, lively and casual. The food is mostly good with occasional fantastic and the odd let down (the tomato salad was good but for around £5 it stung a bit!). Well worth a visit- even if just for a drink!

W7SjQ15YUf8-KaYuvRTsTg.text: Polpo - yummy Italian food but it's a very, very long wait for a table because you can't book

Z0JL3ocNogDx6C-1PKHmww.text: This is a simple place with satisfying food. It was my first experience with Italian tapas, and I can't wait for more. It's been a few months, but I can still make my mouth water by thinking about the rocket salad arancini and little meatball dish. I sat at the bar and had a cocktail, too.

DRc8WnO8-JmgsWnoSGs25A.text: Nice cute little joint in the heart of Soho right off Regent Street. No reservations for dinner but we got there just before 7 on a Monday evening and had no problem. Nice wine, great small plates - from the olives to polenta to yummy prawn risotto and a lamb dish. Nice place to catch up with a friend for dinner after work, which is what I was doing. Casual and homely environment.

RnURYKMBgxUfrU84oIPs_A.text: We had planned to eat at French House après-theatre, but lo and behold, French House the restaurant is closed!  I had read about Polpo (a Venetian bacaro), so a quick search on Google pinpointed the location, and we were off to Plan B.  Once there, the host told us there would be a wait.  No big deal, since a few of my favorite restaurants back home (Chicago) are just the same.  Anyway, so the venue.  It is perhaps fortuitous that Polpo is housed in a building where the blue marker declared that Canaletto, the Venetian court painter, lived here.  Inside, it is all faded industrial chic.  Think Lower-East side Manhattan, Brooklyn, or Wicker Park, Chicago.  The staff, and most of the clientele, are young & hip.  Overall, there was a buzzy lively atmosphere that was very welcoming.  Special mention to the host who stopped over a few times to appraised us of our table situation.  Very nice touch.To start, we had 2 kinds of crostini.  Chopped Chicken Liver, and Rocket & Walnut Pesto.  I have a soft spot for chicken liver crostini.  This one was good, although not a stand out.  The pesto on the other hand was coarse and assertive.  Very good.  Next, Vitello Tonnato.  Again, a dish I have a soft spot for.  And again, good, but not a standout.  The Cotechino sausage had the texture of Spam (just my own opinion).  Flavoring was good though.  The Marinated Sardines, Onions, Raisins and Pine Nuts was the one standout dish of the evening.  The sardines were beautifully seasoned.  The rest of the ingredients provided great textural and flavor contrast, and complement too.  We had a bottle of 2009 Monte del Fra Bardolino Chiaretto, from the Veneto, of course.  The wine list is short and nicely edited, with house wines bearing their label.  It is the height of summer holiday and my instinct tend toward rose.  The Bardolino Chiaretto did not disappoint.  Why 3 stars?  The food at Polpo is generally good and solid, but not standouts.  Polpo is a really fun place with lively atmosphere and really friendly staff.  It is a good place to hang out with your mates, drink, and enjoy a nibble or two.

LOLKjrPSVBGyCKFZoir8XQ.text: Irritating no-reservations policy, made up for in spades with a buzzing atmosphere, great rustic lighting and lovely brown hues, and adorable little dishes such as mackerel tartare with horseradish, or calf's liver with onions and sage. Although many of the menu items are thoughtful and tasty, too few are genuinely adventurous, and there's a tendency towards weak flavours and slightly limp, insipid dishes. But the formula works well and is to be celebrated. The Italian wine list is enjoyable, though limited, and could be substantially improved. The wines are also available in carafes. Polpo almost immediately became a Soho institution and with good reason - it does informal, fun dining with real style.

fOm7NnpOUXINeKFMJ46ouw.text: Don't believe the hype! I went there with a friend from Toronto last Thursday PM and we had a nice drink downstairs in the quirky little bar. We were seated shortly afterwards, the place had a great atmosphere and the staf fairly attentive. Then came the sorry excuse for Italian style tapas food. In short the food was either luke warm, over or under cooked, basic slapped together left overs. Having ordered 8 dishes you would have thought atleast one was worh trying to finish, but sadly not. Trying to add some fun back into the evening I ordered the fail safe doughnuts come profiteroles. Literally one bite of this stale excuse for anything dessert like and that was game over. Go to Polpo to hang out and drink, but not to eat.

Mc3bRq0KPJ72WIxcg_N_zQ.text: I've been to Polpo six times since it opened. I've always had great food and service here. I usually sit at the bar. All good, simple food.  Very similar to neighbourhood Italians in NYC. Really good meal with wine for £35. I love it.. ..and I'm really glad to hear a few whiny people will be freeing up space for me to get a table a bit easier. I'm not sure this restaurant needs picky, over expecting 'foodie' bankers that demand massive plates of food, Michelin chefs and feel the need to publish their pompous stream of waffling consciousness as a judgment on each dish. Fab that you'll be staying away from my lovely neighbourhhood Italian restaurant.

rkEe9042nBGqaxa1Vx9eDw.text: With all the fanfare I honestly thought it would be better. The atmosphere is nice and the menu looks excellent, but the dishes themselves were a bit uninspired. The sardines came out cold. Fair enough it was on purpose, but can't say we really dug it. The fennel salad was boring, as were the beets and the chili prawns. The bruschetta with aubergine was the best thing we tried. It was all OK, but for the price and buzz, I expected more.

88fqsGA-1PM-_8OPFY1QQQ.text: Is it just me or has the West End been invaded by tapas restaurants lately? Dehesa, Opera Tavern, Polpo, Polpette... the list goes on. I use the term "tapas" loosley here to mean Mediterranean sharing plates.... and all of these restaurants are thankfully are a far cry from the dishes of oily chorizo and patatas bravas served up with jugs of sangria that passed for "tapas" 10 years ago. Having heard horror stories of people being unable to get a table by 6.45pm, I turned up at Polpo 6 on the dot and gave them my name for a table of 3. I spent a pleasant hour at the bar quaffing the very nice and reasonably priced house merlot. The staff at the bar knew my name and the service is really friendly and attentive. The place is gorgeous looking with bare tile walls and bulbs hanging over the bar. Wine is served in carafes which adds lots of charm. By the time the last in our party arrived at 7pm the place was heaving, so I was worried that we might be waiting a long time for a table. However, the staff told me that now our whole party was there I was at the top of the list and we got a table 10 minutes later. I won't go on and on about the dishes as lots of others on here have done that in more detail than I can muster the enthusiasm for, but suffice to say that everything was quite nice.... but really didn't blow me away. I would say that the desserts were the highlight: we shared the rum and raisin doughnuts and the panettone bread and butter pudding - both were fabulous. But none of my party were left thinking 'wow' about the meal overall. We spent only around £110 between 3, which I think was excellent value. For me Polpo is one of Soho's finest in terms of atmosphere, but didn't quite nail it with the food.

SJZsDSRgyADKNGvTOZbO1w.text: long wait-definitely make reservations. they have a policy where they won't seat until the entire party is there so keep that in mind!the food is delicious and well priced. and the house wine is also really good. i was a bit disappointed that there wasn't any octopus (the namesake of the restaurant) on the menu however!

BruZ2D10I97IHedPa5odUQ.text: Cracking atmos an top notch food. The liver was wicked. The place is a sort of italian tapa's bar, no reservations taken (apart from lunch i think). Worth the effort.

CLKlcEVWUTxSVjRV5u-U5g.text: Popped in last night for a glass of wine and a little nibble and was delighted to find that it really as charming as people say. Great decor, interesting space, friendly staff. A half litre of white - why does that sound like so much more than 500ml? - a few crostini, a tasty pork belly that was enlivened by the generous sprinkle of toasted hazelnuts and a catch up on gossip with a friend made for a very enjoyable Monday night. When I realised they do Venetian Spritz we had to have one for the road. Total bill of £38 seems like good value in this part of town.
